CLINTON_199_2.input:
CLINTON: "which may prove to be an intelligence benefit
we've got to do everything we can to vacuum up intelligence from Europe, from the Middle East
That means we've got to work more closely with our allies, and that's something that Donald has been very dismissive of
We're working with NATO, the longest military alliance in the history of the world, to really turn our attention to terrorism
We're working with our friends in the Middle East, many of which, as you know, are Muslim majority nations
Donald has consistently insulted Muslims abroad, Muslims at home, when we need to be cooperating with Muslim nations and with the American Muslim community
They're on the front lines
They can provide information to us that we might not get anywhere else
They need to have close working cooperation with law enforcement in these communities, not be alienated and pushed away as some of Donald's rhetoric, unfortunately, has led to"

cqs.cq: Does the potential benefits of intelligence gathering from Muslim nations and communities outweigh the potential risks of alienation and mistrust caused by inflammatory rhetoric from political leaders?

Do you have any concrete evidence that close cooperation with Muslim nations and communities, as Clinton suggests, has led to more effective counter-terrorism efforts than Donald's allegedly "insulting" rhetoric?

If the United States is seeking to gather intelligence from Muslim-majority nations and the American Muslim community, why would the country's rhetoric and actions towards these groups not be considered a form of self-sabotage in the fight against terrorism?

If we're prioritizing intelligence gathering from Muslim nations, does that imply that we're accepting their cooperation as a more valuable asset than the potential harm caused by Donald's rhetoric towards Muslims?

CLINTON_1_2.input:
CLINTON: "If you help create the profits , you should be able to share in them , not just the executives at the top
I want us to do more to support people who are struggling to balance family and work
I 've heard from so many of you about the difficult choices you face and the stresses that you 're under
let 's have paid family leave , earned sick days
Let 's be sure we have affordable child care and debt-free college
How are we going to do it
We 're going to do it by having the wealthy pay their fair share and close the corporate loopholes
we tonight are on the stage together , Donald Trump and I
it 's good to be with you
We 're going to have a debate where we are talking about the important issues facing our country
You have to judge us , who can shoulder the immense , awesome responsibilities of the presidency , who can put into action the plans that will make your life better
I hope that I will be able to earn your vote on November 8th"

cqs.cq: Does the notion that the wealthy should pay their fair share and close corporate loopholes actually cause a significant reduction in the economic burden on middle-class families, rather than merely redistributing the wealth?

Can you provide evidence that the proposed policies you outlined, such as paid family leave, affordable child care, and debt-free college, have been successfully implemented in any country or state, or are they merely theoretical solutions?

If Clinton's proposed policies aim to reduce the wealth gap and improve the lives of working Americans, would it not be hypocritical for her to prioritize the interests of the wealthy and large corporations over those of the middle and lower classes?
If the wealthy are expected to pay their fair share and close corporate loopholes, then how can the executives at the top be exempt from this responsibility?

CLINTON_21.input:
CLINTON: "nine million people lost their jobs
Five million people lost their homes
$ 13 trillion in family wealth was wiped out
Now , we have come back from that abyss
it has not been easy
we 're now on the precipice of having a potentially much better economy
the last thing we need to do is to go back to the policies that failed us in the first place
Independent experts have looked at what I 've proposed
looked at what Donald 's proposed
I intend to get it done
Take clean energy
Some country is going to be the clean- energy superpower of the 21st century
Donald thinks that climate change is a hoax perpetrated by the Chinese
I think it 's real"

cqs.cq: Would implementing policies that address climate change, as proposed by Clinton, potentially mitigate the economic instability and financial losses that occurred during the economic downturn?

Do you have any independent expert opinions that support the claim that the economic policies of the past, which failed, are the only viable solution for the current economic situation, rather than exploring alternative approaches?

If the US economy was able to recover from the devastating losses of the 2008 recession, why would a return to failed policies necessarily preclude the possibility of recovering from the consequences of climate change?
If the economy has indeed recovered after the devastating losses, then why are the economic policies that failed during that crisis still being considered as potential solutions?

CLINTON_223_1.input:
CLINTON: "Let 's talk about two important issues that were briefly mentioned by Donald
first , NATO
NATO as a military alliance has something called Article 5
you know the only time it 's ever been invoked ?
After 9/11 , when the 28 nations of NATO said that they would go to Afghanistan with us to fight terrorism
something that they still are doing by our side
With respect to Iran , when I became secretary of state , Iran was weeks away from having enough nuclear material to form a bomb
They had mastered the nuclear fuel cycle under the Bush administration
They had built covert facilities
They had stocked them with centrifuges that were whirling away
we had sanctioned them"

cqs.cq: What if the invocation of Article 5 by NATO after 9/11 causes the alliance to become overly reliant on US leadership, thereby affecting the decision-making process in the region?
Do you have any evidence from your experience as Secretary of State that suggests the Iranian nuclear threat was as imminent as you described, or was it a more nuanced assessment?

If the 28 nations of NATO invoked Article 5 to fight terrorism in Afghanistan, does that imply that they would also invoke it to support the US in a conflict with Iran, despite Iran's nuclear advancements?
If the United States and its allies invoked Article 5 to fight terrorism, why did they not invoke it to prevent Iran from developing nuclear capabilities under the Bush administration?

CLINTON_223_2.input:
CLINTON: "I voted for every sanction against Iran when I was in the Senate
it was n't enough
I spent a year-and-a-half putting together a coalition that included Russia and China to impose the toughest sanctions on Iran
 we did drive them to the negotiating table
my successor , John Kerry , and President Obama got a deal that put a lid on Iran 's nuclear program without firing a single shot
That 's diplomacy
That 's coalition-building
That 's working with other nations
That 's not good judgment"

cqs.cq: If the diplomatic approach was successful in achieving the desired outcome, then why did Clinton imply that her own approach, which also achieved the same outcome, was not good judgment?

Can you provide evidence that your diplomatic efforts with Russia and China, as you described, were the sole reason for Iran's nuclear program being "put on the lid" and not the result of a broader geopolitical strategy?
Does the fact that Clinton's diplomatic efforts led to a deal without military action imply that military action is not the only effective means of achieving foreign policy goals?
Does imposing sanctions on North Korea, despite past failures to achieve desired outcomes with Iran, justify the potential risks of escalation and potential harm to innocent civilians?

CLINTON_225.input: CLINTON: "That is not the right temperament to be commander-in- chief , to be taunted"

cqs.cq: What if having a commander-in-chief who is prone to being taunted undermines the ability to effectively handle high-pressure situations and affect the country's foreign policy decisions?

Can you provide a single instance of a scientific study or a reputable source that supports your claim that a president's temperament is the sole determining factor for their ability to hold the office of commander-in-chief?
If a president's leadership style is deemed unsuitable due to being "taunted," would that same standard apply to a politician who is constantly criticized and mocked by their opponents?
If he cannot handle taunting from other nations, how can he be expected to make tough decisions in the face of international pressure?

CLINTON_231.input:
CLINTON: "in fact , his cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons is so deeply troubling
That is the number-one threat we face in the world
it becomes particularly threatening if terrorists ever get their hands on any nuclear material"

cqs.cq: Does the President's cavalier attitude towards nuclear weapons increase the likelihood of terrorists acquiring nuclear material?
Does President Clinton's emphasis on the threat of nuclear terrorism align with the assessment of the international community, or is it a biased perspective?
If a president's cavalier attitude towards nuclear weapons is a number-one threat to the world, would his response to a similar threat from a foreign nation be seen as equally concerning?

Doesn't President Clinton's depiction of nuclear weapons as the number-one threat imply that he views the proliferation of nuclear power itself as inherently more perilous than the cavalier attitude of the individual possessing it?

CLINTON_235.input:
CLINTON: "It 's a good one , though
It well describes the problem"

cqs.cq: Does this description of the problem, though good, cause the lack of effective solutions to the problem?
Can you provide a scientific source or personal experience that supports your claim about the effectiveness of a solution described as "good one" in addressing the problem?
If white Americans can be considered Americans after one generation, wouldn't people of color also be considered Americans after one generation?
If the statement you made is a good one, does that imply that you also see the problem as being a positive aspect?

CLINTON_244_2.input:
CLINTON: "If he 's going to criticize a deal that has been very successful in giving us access to Iranian facilities that we never had before , then he should tell us what his alternative would be
it 's like his plan to defeat ISIS
the only secret is that he has no plan
He says it 's a secret plan
we need to be more precise in how we talk about these issues
People around the word follow our presidential campaigns so closely , trying to get hints about what we will do
Can they rely on us ?
Are we going to lead the world with strength and in accordance with our values ?
That 's what I intend to do
I intend to be a leader of our country that people can count on , both here at home and around the world
to make decisions that will further peace and prosperity
also stand up to bullies , whether they 're abroad or at home
We can not let those who would try to destabilize the world to interfere with American interests and security"

cqs.cq: Does a lack of a clear alternative plan by a presidential candidate undermine the credibility of their claims to lead the country with strength and in accordance with its values?
Does the claim that a president should reveal their secret plan to defeat ISIS, as Clinton suggests, align with the traditional understanding of presidential secrecy and diplomacy?

If the President is expected to be a leader who can be counted on to further peace and prosperity, why is the decision to criticize a deal with Iran seen as a more reliable indicator of his leadership approach than the lack of a specific plan to defeat ISIS?
Does the fact that you are criticizing the deal while not offering a viable alternative undermine your claim that you can be a leader that people can count on?

CLINTON_25.input:
CLINTON: "it 's important that we grip this and deal with it , both at home and abroad
here 's what we can do
We can deploy a half a billion more solar panels
We can have enough clean energy to power every home
We can build a new modern electric grid
That 's a lot of jobs
that 's a lot of new economic activity
 I 've tried to be very specific about what we can and should do
I am determined that we 're going to get the economy really moving again , building on the progress we 've made over the last eight years , but never going back to what got us in trouble in the first place"

cqs.cq: What if deploying a half a billion more solar panels causes a surge in manufacturing costs, which affects the economic activity and job growth that Clinton is advocating for?
Does the deployment of a half a billion solar panels and building a new modern electric grid align with the long-term economic and environmental goals you've previously emphasized?

If deploying a half a billion more solar panels and building a new modern electric grid is a significant step towards a clean energy future, would it not be equally important to also address the economic and social disparities that are hindering the progress of marginalized communities?

If the president has emphasized the importance of addressing the issue both domestically and internationally, then why is the focus primarily on domestic solutions rather than a more comprehensive, global approach to address the root causes of the problem?

CLINTON_37.input:
CLINTON: " Some of them I voted for
The biggest one, a multinational one known as CAFTA, I voted against
I hold the same standards as I look at all of these trade deals
let's not assume that trade is the only challenge we have in the economy
it is a part of it
I'm going to have a special prosecutor
We're going to enforce the trade deals we have, and we're going to hold people accountable
When I was secretary of state, we actually increased American exports globally 30 percent
We increased them to China 50 percent
 know how to really work to get new jobs and to get exports that helped to create more new jobs"

cqs.cq: Does the secretary's past experience in increasing American exports to China not cause a decrease in domestic jobs in the manufacturing sector?
Can you provide evidence that the 30% increase in American exports during your tenure as Secretary of State directly resulted in the creation of new jobs rather than just an increase in exports?

Does the former secretary of state's claim that she increased American exports by 30% globally and 50% to China while in office directly translate to her ability to effectively address the complex issues she mentioned in her speech?
If the former secretary of state increased exports to China by 50 percent, does that not contradict the claim that the current trade deals are not being enforced effectively?

CLINTON_39.input:
CLINTON: "I've been a senator, Donald
...
You haven't done it.
 I have been a secretary of state
And I have done a lot"

cqs.cq: Does his past experience as a secretary of state necessarily mean he has more experience than his claim that he has done a lot?

Does your experience as a senator and secretary of state qualify you as more qualified to hold the office than someone who has built a successful business empire and has no prior government experience?
Does her experience as a senator and secretary of state make her a more qualified presidential candidate than someone who has never held such positions?
If he has been a senator and a secretary of state, then what makes him more qualified to be president than you, who have held the same positions?

CLINTON_55.input:
CLINTON: "There are different views about what's good for our country, our economy, and our leadership in the world
it's important to look at what we need to do to get the economy going again
new jobs with rising incomes, investments, not in more tax cuts that would add $5 trillion to the debt"

cqs.cq: Will the economic growth and rising incomes that come from creating new jobs outweigh the negative effects of adding $5 trillion to the national debt?
Do you have any evidence from reputable economic sources that supports the claim that tax cuts are more effective at stimulating the economy than investing in new jobs and rising incomes?

Does Clinton's economic plan, which prioritizes job creation and investments over tax cuts, reflect a more nuanced understanding of the complex relationships between economic growth, national prosperity, and global leadership?
If Clinton is prioritizing the economy over other aspects, does this imply that economic growth is more vital to the country than the other concerns she mentioned?

CLINTON_57.input:
CLINTON: "you have no plan
I have written a book about it. It's called "Stronger Together."
You can pick it up tomorrow at a bookstore
we need to have strong growth , fair growth , sustained growth
We also have to look at how we help families balance the responsibilities at home and the responsibilities at business
we have a very robust set of plans
people have looked at both of our plans , have concluded that mine would create 10 million jobs and yours would lose us 3.5 million jobs , and explode the debt which would have a recession"

cqs.cq: Does the fact that Clinton's plan would allegedly create 10 million jobs and her opponent's plan would result in a recession indicate a cause-and-effect relationship where the proposed policies have a significant impact on the country's economic trajectory?

Do you have any empirical evidence from your book "Stronger Together" that supports your claim that your economic plan would create 10 million jobs, or is that a hypothetical assertion without scientific backing?
If Clinton's plan is to create 10 million jobs and his opponent's plan would lead to a recession, does that not imply that his plan is more viable and effective than his opponent's?
If your book "Stronger Together" is supposed to be a plan for economic growth, how can it simultaneously create 10 million jobs while your opponent's plan would allegedly lose us 3.5 million jobs?

CLINTON_66.input:
CLINTON: "what I have proposed would not add a penny to the debt
 your plans would add $ 5 trillion to the debt
What I have proposed would cut regulations and streamline them for small businesses
What I have proposed would be paid for by raising taxes on the wealthy
they have made all the gains in the economy
it 's time that the wealthy and corporations paid their fair share to support this country"

cqs.cq: Does the potential increase in debt caused by the opposing party's plan justify the proposed tax increases on the wealthy and corporations to support the country?

Can you provide evidence from a credible economic expert that supports the claim that raising taxes on the wealthy would lead to a net increase in government revenue, rather than just a shift in the tax burden?

If the wealthy and corporations have profited from the economy, why should they not be held accountable for contributing to the nation's finances through tax increases rather than solely relying on the Clinton's proposed plan to cut regulations?
If the wealthy and corporations have made all the gains in the economy, then shouldn't they be responsible for paying their fair share, even if it means adding a trillion to the debt?

CLINTON_6_1.input:
CLINTON: "we are 5 percent of the world 's population ; we have to trade with the other 95 percent
we need to have smart , fair trade deals
We also , though , need to have a tax system that rewards work and not just financial transactions
the kind of plan that Donald has put forth would be trickle-down economics all over again
it would be the most extreme version , the biggest tax cuts for the top percent of the people in this country than we 've ever had
trumped-up trickle-down , because that 's exactly what it would be
That is not how we grow the economy
We just have a different view about what 's best for growing the economy , how we make investments that will actually produce jobs and rising incomes
we come at it from somewhat different perspectives
Donald was very fortunate in his life , and that 's all to his benefit"

cqs.cq: Does having a tax system that rewards work over financial transactions necessarily cause a more equitable distribution of wealth and economic growth?

Do you have any empirical evidence to support the claim that a tax system that rewards work over financial transactions is more effective in growing the economy than the trickle-down economics proposed by Donald?
If the 95% of the global population that the US does not trade with can afford to be described as "fortunate" in their lives, why would the same description not apply to the wealthy 1% in the US?
Does a system that rewards work over financial transactions necessarily equate to a more effective approach to economic growth than one that prioritizes trickle-down economics?

CLINTON_6_2.input:
CLINTON: "He started his business with $ 14 million , borrowed from his father
he really believes that the more you help wealthy people , the better off we 'll be and that everything will work out from there
I do n't buy that
I have a different experience
My father was a small-businessman
He worked really hard
He printed drapery fabrics on long tables, where he pulled out those fabrics and he went down with a silkscreen and dumped the paint in and took the squeegee and kept going
what I believe is the more we can do for the middle class, the more we can invest in you, your education, your skills, your future
the better we will be off and the better we'll grow
That's the kind of economy I want us to see again"

cqs.cq: Does the businessman's own experience of being born into a lower-middle-class family, where his father worked hard to make a living, influence his views on economic policies, contrasting with his current stance on helping the wealthy?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that the economic success of one's business directly correlates with their wealth and status?
Does the wealth and privilege of a business owner, such as Clinton's father, not inherently resemble the same privilege that wealthy individuals, like his son, are supposed to help?
If his father's business success was solely based on borrowed money, can his son's business success be considered a genuine achievement rather than a privilege of family connections?

CLINTON_85.input:
CLINTON: "let 's start the clock again , Lester
We 've looked at your tax proposals
I do n't see changes in the corporate tax rates or the kinds of proposals you 're referring to that would cause the repatriation , bringing back of money that 's stranded overseas
I happen to support that"

cqs.cq: If the repatriation of money that's stranded overseas doesn't occur, do you think the current corporate tax rates would have a significant impact on the decisions made by companies to invest in the US economy?
Do you have any empirical evidence that supports the claim that tax rate changes would directly lead to the repatriation of money currently stranded overseas?

If CLINTON's proposals would not cause repatriation, bringing back of money that's stranded overseas, would this not be an example of his own policies not being effective in achieving their intended goals?
If the President supports repatriation, then why does he not advocate for immediate action, rather than starting the clock again?

CLINTON_87.input:
CLINTON: "I happen to support that in a way that will actually work to our benefit
when I look at what you have proposed , you have what is called now the Trump loophole
it would so advantage you and the business you do"

cqs.cq: Does the Trump loophole, as described by Clinton, inherently cause a significant shift in the balance of power and influence, ultimately affecting the outcome of the proposed policy?
Does your support for the "Trump loophole" align with the principles of democratic values and public interest, or is it merely a strategic maneuver to benefit your business interests?
Does Clinton's support for the Trump loophole imply that she would prioritize personal gain over the principles she claims to stand for?
Does Clinton's support for the proposal that benefits Trump also imply that she is willing to compromise her principles for short-term gains?

CLINTON_92.input:
CLINTON: "it is
trumped-up trickle-down
Trickle-down did not work
It got us into the mess we were in , in 2008 and 2009
Slashing taxes on the wealthy has n't worked
a lot of really smart , wealthy people know that
they are saying , hey , we need to do more to make the contributions we should be making to rebuild the middle class
I do n't think top-down works in America
building the middle class , investing in the middle class , making college debt-free so more young people can get their education , helping people refinance their—their debt from college at a lower rate
Those are the kinds of things that will really boost the economy
Broad-based , inclusive growth is what we need in America , not more advantages for people at the very top"

cqs.cq: What if the trickle-down approach, which Clinton suggests has historically failed, causes the widening of the wealth gap, thereby hindering the growth of the middle class?
Do you have any empirical evidence to support the claim that trickle-down economics has failed in America, considering the 2008 and 2009 economic crisis?

Would the trickle-down economic approach advocated by Clinton be considered analogous to trickle-down justice, where the benefits of economic growth trickle down to the middle class rather than being held by those at the top?
If trickle-down economics failed to address the economic issues in 2008 and 2009, can the current economic policies of the top 1% truly be expected to lift the entire middle class?

CL_57.input:
CL: "Well, both sides of the transaction suffer as a result of ignoring moral hazard
because moral hazard is a natural part of the process of lending and borrowing
And if you suppress it, then in fact you're in a situation where the wealth that you look like you're generating is fool’s gold, not real wealth at all."

cqs.cq: What if suppressing moral hazard leads to a situation where the perceived wealth is actually a mirage, rather than a genuine reflection of the true value of the transaction?
Do you have a study or economic model that demonstrates a direct correlation between the suppression of moral hazard and the creation of "fool's gold" in lending and borrowing?
If moral hazard is a natural part of the process of lending and borrowing, would ignoring it essentially equate to creating a system where wealth is not accurately valued?
If moral hazard is a natural part of lending and borrowing, then wouldn't the wealth generated by suppressing it be equally illusory?

Doctor-Mom_205.input:
Doctor-Mom: "I would support a full ban of peanut products on any airline.
Peanut reactions can be life threatening.
An individual doesn't have to consume the product to have a life threatening reaction.
They can have contact or inhalation reactions.
Restricting to certain flights is not enough,
as residue can be rampant.
Providing buffer zones is a thoughtful gesture,
but from a practical point of view does not work.
With so many food choices available, why are peanuts a necessary choice?
I am a physician , and author on the subject.
I have free food allergy online support forums with 3000 members.
http://www.drmomsallergyrx.com/
I would be more than willing to work with you in any way on this decision making process.
The allergic community is so grateful that you are allowing our voices to be heard.
The decision you are considering could save many lives."

cqs.cq: Would the implementation of a full ban on peanut products on any airline cause a significant decrease in peanut-related reactions among passengers, or would it merely shift the risk to other areas, such as airports and public spaces?

Can you provide evidence from your 3000-member online support forum or any peer-reviewed medical journal that supports your claim that peanut-free flights are a matter of life or death for a significant portion of airline passengers?

If a physician and author with a platform of 3000 members is advocating for a ban on peanuts on airlines due to potential life-threatening reactions, why should the airline industry prioritize convenience over passenger safety?

If a physician who claims to prioritize the well-being of patients with life-threatening peanut allergies can advocate for a complete ban on peanut products on airlines, then why is she not also pushing for a complete ban on peanuts in all public spaces and environments where exposure to peanuts could be fatal?

Elmattador__92.input:
Elmattador: "you must have missed the GOP debates"
 < this message is answering to > 
Bigtwinkie: "This debate has honestly been making me uncomfortable
its been way too hostile
Its like listening to mom and dad fight in the kitchen while your hide under the covers in your room
 all they succeed at is making the entire panel seem unlikable
the democratic nominee will be bleeding votes no matter who wins"

cqs.cq: Does the tone of the debate itself inadvertently cause the public to become disillusioned with the entire political process?
Do you think the current state of the GOP debates is a reflection of the party's values or a symptom of a larger issue with the political landscape?
Does the Republican debate's tone and dynamics mirror the divisive family arguments at home, potentially reflecting poorly on the party rather than the candidates?
If the debate is indeed as uncomfortable as you describe, do the hosts and moderators not bear some responsibility for fostering a more constructive and respectful discussion?

FoodAllergyMom_199_1.input:
FoodAllergyMom: "My child is 2 years old and he is severely allergic to peanuts, tree nuts, egg and milk.
My son has reacted to airborne particles from someone opening a bag of nuts near him.
My husband and I used to be world traveler's and dreamed of traveling with our son.
It is heartbreaking to think that our child will not get to experience the world, or if he does it may cost him his life.
What about when he gets older and his job requires him to fly across the country in a weekend?
Should he have to risk his life so he can work in his possible future dream job?
This is a disability, no question about it.
We are talking about being in the air with peanut particles being circulated through the cabin and possible no place to land for hours.
An EpiPen only last 15 minutes.
Peanut allergy is unpredictable.
The first reaction could be mild
and the second could cause your blood pressure to drop like a rocket, your throat to close up and your heart to stop beating."

cqs.cq: What if the severity of his food allergies causes his future employers to be unwilling to accommodate his needs, thereby affecting his job prospects and potential career advancement?

Does the burden of a child's severe food allergy outweigh the potential benefits of traveling and exploring the world, particularly when considering the unpredictable nature of the allergy and the limited effectiveness of emergency response measures like EpiPens?

If a peanut allergy is considered a disability that can be life-threatening, why should it be treated as a personal choice rather than a medical condition that warrants accommodations and protections?
Should we prioritize the freedom to pursue one's career aspirations over the safety of individuals with severe food allergies?

Frequent-Flyer_157.input:
Frequent-Flyer: "I have sympathy for those with peanut allergies,
but banning peanuts from flights via a DOT regulation seems to go too far.
Perhaps advocacy groups for those who are peanutallergic will approach the major carriers to voluntarily set aside seating blocks that are reserved for allergy sufferers, and nonsufferers who are willing to agree not to eat peanuts while sitting in that particular block.
As someone who suffers from a medical condition which requires me to carry my "rescue" medication with me everywhere I go,
I think that if the risk to an allergy sufferer is deemed to be significant, then they should
consider alternate travel methods other than flying,
ensure they have sufficient "rescue" medication to last the entire time they might be stuck in an aircraft,
they should wear appropriate clothing / face masks to minimize exposed skin and inhalation risk.
Requiring other passengers to forgo their "right" to eat peanuts so as to accommodate the "right" of allergy sufferers to fly seems a bit much,
particularly if the allergy sufferers don't fly often, anyway."

cqs.cq: What if the risk of peanut allergies is so significant that it causes frequent flyers to avoid flights altogether, would that not be a more effective solution than relying on voluntary accommodations from airlines?
Do you believe that requiring airlines to ban peanuts on flights due to a medical condition is a more significant burden on passengers than accommodating the needs of peanut-allergic individuals?
If individuals with peanut allergies have a right to fly, would the same right extend to individuals with other severe food allergies, such as shellfish or gluten allergies?

If the airline industry can accommodate allergy sufferers with voluntary seating blocks, then why can't they also accommodate those with other medical conditions requiring rescue medication by providing similar accommodations?

Glblwrmingisfak__552.input:
Glblwrmingisfak: "What argument?
Nobody proposes common sense gun solutions
The DOJ over a decade ago already determined that an assault weapons ban won't do shit for addressing homicide rates in the US
It is not a solution for any of our problems
Bernie should know
he clearly isn't stupid"

cqs.cq: If the effectiveness of an assault weapons ban is already determined to be negligible by the DOJ, does that justify its rejection as a viable solution to address the country's homicide rates?
Do you have any evidence from the DOJ's decade-old study that suggests banning assault weapons would not have a significant impact on addressing homicide rates in the US?

If the United States has seen no significant reduction in homicide rates despite decades of gun control efforts, why would Bernie's proposed solutions be expected to be effective in addressing the issue?
If the DOJ has already determined that an assault weapons ban won't address homicide rates, how can Bernie propose it as a solution without being accused of being ignorant of the facts?

HOLT_126.input:
HOLT: "Stop-and-frisk was ruled unconstitutional in New York
it largely singled out black and Hispanic young men"

cqs.cq: Does the practice of stop-and-frisk disproportionately target and affect the civil rights of black and Hispanic young men in New York, leading to further marginalization and systemic inequality?
Do you have a study or evidence that supports the claim that the racial bias in the Stop-and-frisk policy was not a significant factor in its unconstitutionality?
If stop-and-frisk was deemed unconstitutional for targeting black and Hispanic young men, would the same logic not apply to the historical targeting of African Americans with restrictive voting laws?
If stop-and-frisk was ruled unconstitutional due to its racial bias, doesn't the same logic apply to any law enforcement tactic that disproportionately targets minority groups?

HOLT_239.input:
HOLT: "Which leads to my next question
we enter our last segment here on the , still on the subject of securing America
On nuclear weapons , President Obama reportedly considered changing the nation 's longstanding policy on first use
Do you support the current policy ?
Mr. Trump , you have two minutes on that"

cqs.cq: Does the current policy on first use of nuclear weapons lead to increased global instability and a heightened risk of nuclear war?
Do you have any evidence that the current nuclear first-use policy has been effective in deterring potential adversaries and preventing nuclear proliferation?

If the president's decision on nuclear weapons can be likened to a household's decision on when to use a fire extinguisher, would that household's safety be compromised if they waited until the house is fully engulfed in flames?
If President Obama considered changing the nation's policy on first use, does this imply that the current policy is not effective in securing America?

HOLT_94.input:
HOLT: "we 're talking about the burden that Americans have to pay , yet you have not released your tax returns
the reason nominees have released their returns for decades is so that voters will know if their potential president owes money to—who he owes it to and any business conflicts
Do n't Americans have a right to know if there are any conflicts of interest"

cqs.cq: Does the lack of transparency in the tax returns of a presidential nominee cause a conflict of interest that affects the decisions made on policies that impact the American people?

Does releasing tax returns by presidential nominees serve as a precedent for transparency and accountability, rather than a voluntary act, thus implying that a lack of disclosure may inherently compromise the integrity of the democratic process?
If nominees release their tax returns to reveal potential conflicts of interest, why should a president who has been in office for decades also not be held to the same standard?

If the nominees' tax returns are a prerequisite for transparency and accountability, then shouldn't the President's tax returns be a necessary step in maintaining the trust and integrity of the office?

Helen__66.input:
Helen: "they’re not able to impose the right sort of levels
and within that bracket I would certainly put families who are living with very high levels of aggression and violence, who are terrorising communities
So, yes I’d agree with that
But I would also say that there are other families, where actually they do need a great deal of help
it’s right to intervene
and actually you can help them get back on their feet and able to parent their children effectively"

cqs.cq: If we prioritize intervening in families with high levels of aggression and violence, then should we also be providing support to families who are struggling, potentially causing a potential shift in the overall approach to family assistance?
Do you believe that your statement about intervening in families with high levels of aggression and violence is supported by empirical evidence, rather than just anecdotal experience?

If families with high levels of aggression and violence can be seen as in need of intervention, why should families with high levels of aggression and violence in the context of systemic oppression not also be seen as in need of systemic intervention?

If Helen believes that some families require intervention due to high levels of aggression and violence, doesn't she also imply that the state of being unable to impose the right levels of aggression and violence in other families is a form of neglect?

17th_knight__247.input:
17th: "They should get the coverage
They are here
they work
they are a part of this society
Fuck off with your xenophobia"
 < this message is answering to > 
reaper527: "now you have a field of democrat presidential candidates supporting it
republicans used to get mocked and laughed at when they said that illegal immigrants would be getting obamacare coverage"

cqs.cq: If the undocumented immigrants are granted coverage, would it not also lead to a surge in their numbers, potentially affecting the overall demographic and economic landscape of the country?

Do you think the comparison between xenophobic attitudes towards immigrants and the current support for healthcare coverage for undocumented immigrants from presidential candidates is a valid argument?

If illegal immigrants can be granted access to healthcare through Obamacare, would this not also justify providing equal access to other basic rights and benefits, such as education and employment opportunities, to those who are already a part of this society?
If they deserve coverage and are part of society, should we then extend that same treatment to undocumented immigrants, regardless of the initial mockery and political party affiliations?

AFCHF_154.input:
AFCHF: "DOT should set maximum tarmac delay trigger.
It then should apply to ALL AIRLINES and ALL CLASSES of AIRCRAFT.
The airlines need to make a legal committment (contract of carriage).
Deplaneing without CBP screening IS a viable option.
As a military member, I have done this many times during overseas contract flights.
I realize this is customs rather than airport security, but the concept is the same.
Allow passengers to deplane during gate holds,
but require them to remain in the immediate area.
This is no different than an openended delay prior to boarding."

cqs.cq: What if the increased tarmac delay trigger set by DOT leads to a surge in passenger deplaning, and does this impact the overall efficiency of airport operations and the potential for more significant disruptions?
Do you have a legal or regulatory basis to support the claim that airlines are contractually obligated to allow passengers to deplane during gate holds without CBP screening?

If airlines can allow passengers to deplane during gate holds, why would that same privilege not be extended to passengers during tarmac delays, which could also be considered a form of open-ended delay prior to boarding?

If the airline industry can already accommodate gate holds, why should the Transportation Department set a maximum tarmac delay trigger, and would this not create an uneven application across all airlines and aircraft classes?

AK-traveler_186.input:
AK-traveler: "Airlines should not be allowed to charge for items necessary because of factors out of the passengers control.
Seat size and configuration (arm and leg room) should be addressed as a health issue.
The inflight magazines show exercises passengers should do at their seats to prevent deep vein thrombosis
but there isn't enough room to do them.
And finally, I think it is unfair if not criminal and discriminatory to charge exorbinant fees for carrying your pet onboard with you.
The carrier is handled as a carry on bag solely by me,
the airline doesn't do anything
yet they carage $100 or more each way."

cqs.cq: Does the lack of adequate seat size and configuration cause a higher risk of deep vein thrombosis among passengers, thereby affecting their health and potentially influencing their decision to travel by air?

Do you consider the airline industry's prioritization of passenger comfort and health as a legitimate reason to justify charging for essential items that passengers cannot control, such as pet fees, in light of the fact that airlines profit from these charges?
If airlines charge passengers for items necessary due to factors out of their control, why should passengers not be charged for their pets, which are also a factor outside of their control?
If airlines are prioritizing passenger health by providing in-flight exercises to prevent deep vein thrombosis, then why don't they also provide sufficient seat space to accommodate these exercises?

AllergyDad_200.input:
AllergyDad: "As a parent of a child with severe lifethreatening allergies to peanuts and treenuts, the thought of getting on an airplane today is frightening.
So much so, that it is strictly avoided.
It is not worth risking my child's life to fly on an airplane.
A recent study reveals that 1 in 3 airplane reactions was anaphylaxis
(Allergic Living Magazine).
I don't like those odds.
The substitution of cashews, walnuts, or other tree nuts is not a viable option,
as they pose the same risks as peanuts.
A large number of people who are allergic to peanuts are also allergic to tree nuts,
plus they are typically processed in a plant that also processes peanuts.
If there were a ban on peanut and tree nut products on flights, it would open the world to my son.
He didn't choose to be allergic,
but he is.
So true.
We are not talking about sensitivity, being offended, not liking the smell, etc.;
we are talking about life.
There are a lot of things that are banned from airplanes that can cause death to someone.
In the case of my son, a peanut can have the same result.
I urge the DOT to issue the ban,
and make traveling safe for everyone."

cqs.cq: What if the potential risk of anaphylaxis caused by peanuts and tree nuts on flights leads to a ban on these products, would it ultimately affect the overall airline industry's ability to provide a safe and inclusive travel experience for passengers with allergies?
Do you have a scientific source that confirms the assertion that banning peanut and tree nut products on flights would effectively eliminate the risk of anaphylaxis for all passengers with allergies?

If the DOT bans peanuts and tree nuts from flights due to the risks of anaphylaxis, should they not also consider banning other foods that pose similar health risks, such as shellfish and dairy products?
If the airline industry can already ban products that pose a risk of death to passengers, why should peanuts, which have a proven track record of causing anaphylaxis, be exempt from this policy?

AngelComa__638.input:
AngelComa: "Funny, I thought he did good
They get timed responses
his plan is all there
He can't talk about everything in the plan
Must be how used you are to politicians saying things and not having a plan"
 < this message is answering to > 
Punchee: "That was a weird moment in American debate history. "Yo check my website. Shit's on there.""

cqs.cq: What if the lack of transparency in the politician's plan is a cause for the public's skepticism about his ability to deliver on his promises?

Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that a politician's ability to articulate their plan is a more significant indicator of their effectiveness than their actual track record of implementing policies?
Does the expectation of transparency in a politician's plan and its execution justify the assumption that a lack of verbal explanation of the plan itself is an indicator of dishonesty?
Doesn't he, who has a plan but can't talk about it, lack the transparency and accountability that citizens expect from their leaders?

Antanagoge_104.input:
Antanagoge: "The airline industry can not be left to selfmonitor this.
Studies have shown that the quality of information from airline customer service department is highly variable and, in some cases, incomplete or inaccurate.
The psychological effects of this, combined with the risk of death, are significant.
Stories told by families of vacations never taken, of midair retraction of the promise by the airline that peanuts would not be served, of public humiliation of peanutallergic individuals and their family by airline staff, and of serious reactions in flight, abound."

cqs.cq: If airlines are responsible for the well-being and safety of their passengers, then how can they justify the lack of a standardized and reliable information system that would minimize the psychological and health impacts of their variable and sometimes inaccurate customer service?

Do you have a study or evidence that supports the claim that the airline industry's self-regulation is effective in mitigating the psychological and health risks associated with inconsistent and inaccurate customer service?

If airline customers are consistently misled by incomplete or inaccurate information, would it not be analogous to the airline industry's responsibility to ensure accurate information to be comparable to a doctor's responsibility to provide accurate medical diagnoses?

If airline self-regulation is so effective, then why would we need to impose stricter regulations when customer service information is often incomplete or inaccurate, potentially putting passengers at risk?

Antanagoge_111.input:
Antanagoge: "The opponents of accommodations are well aware that studies have been published in the journals of the American Academy of Allergy Asthma and Immunology, the American Medical Association, and the American College of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology, not to mention medical associations in other countries.
They can purchase full text access for themselves,
but they already have a prejudgment against the researchers and their conclusions,
so why bother?
There was a moment on the board when the moderators asked for a discussion of a hypothetical compromise position.
But those demanding funerals before entertaining even a compromise position muted that.
That is sad.
There are several others on the board with some good reasonable ideas.
It's fairly clear that meanspiritedness abounds, here
probably as a result of emphasis in current American politics on the potential for influence of minority interests and needs.
But some of the people on this board  calling for funerals before advancing the discussion  give new meaning to the Founders' fears of the tyranny of the majority."

cqs.cq: Would the dismissal of a compromise position by those with a prejudgment against the researchers undermine the effectiveness of the board's goal to facilitate a constructive dialogue about the studies?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that the moderators of the board in question have a prejudgment against the researchers and their conclusions?

If the American Academy of Allergy Asthma and Immunology's research is disregarded by the opponents due to prejudice, why would their conclusions be given more weight than those of researchers from diverse backgrounds?

If the opponents of accommodations have already been exposed to the research and still harbor a prejudgment against it, does that not undermine their claim to be objective and impartial in their criticism?

Antanagoge_227.input:
Antanagoge: "Peanut allergens are indeed present in the recirculated air in the aircraft cabin.
This study, "Recovery of peanut allergens from ventilation filters of commercial airliners," ? conducted "to help address whether peanutsensitive travelers are exposed to peanut aeroallergans during airline flights on which peanuts are served" ? resulted in the conclusion that "that peanut allergens can be eluted from ventilation system filters in commercial airliners. The most likely source of these allergens are the peanuts served during flights." ?
http://download.journals.elsevierhealth.com/pdfs/journals/00916749/PIIS0091674996811791.pdf"
 < this message is answering to > 
Mulder: "Apparently Samsmom is the ignorant one.
She attacks what she clearly does not understand.
If her child has a true peanut allergy that is so severe, he shouldn't be flying,
since her argument is that any contact with peanut dust or oil would cause anaphylactic shock.
Since that possibility is very real even outside an airline cabin,
she's making her own argument for living in a bubble.
Facts are stubborn things,
and one of those facts is that the air onboard an airliner is cleaner than in most public buildings,
so there's very little, if any, real risk involved in flying on a jet where peanuts have been consumed before or are even being served now.
Another stubborn fact is that you can be desensitized to peanut allergies,
but if you're unwilling to do it, don't blame others for not bending to your petty fears.
Nobody has studied this subject,
so there's no hard data.
But we do know that the air onboard an airliner is much cleaner than people think.
Only one confirmed death onboard an airliner has been reported,
but it may have been as far back as 1998,
and it was an Eastern European airline."

cqs.cq: Do the findings of the study that peanut allergens can be eluted from ventilation system filters in commercial airliners support the claim that the risk of anaphylactic shock from peanut dust or oil in the aircraft cabin is a significant concern for passengers with severe peanut allergies?

Does the study you cited, "Recovery of peanut allergens from ventilation filters of commercial airliners," provide evidence to support your claim that the air onboard an airliner is cleaner than in most public buildings, when it concludes that peanut allergens can be eluted from ventilation system filters in commercial airliners?

If peanut allergens can indeed be eluted from ventilation system filters in commercial airliners, does it not make sense that this could be a more significant concern than a hypothetical anaphylactic shock from airborne peanut dust?

If the air onboard an airliner is indeed cleaner than in most public buildings, as you claim, then why does the fact that peanut allergens can be eluted from ventilation system filters pose a significant risk for peanut-sensitive travelers, as you seem to suggest?

Antanagoge_239.input:
Antanagoge: "Is it really possible that all blindly partisan advocates of the peanut in this context eat peanuts and only peanuts?
That they are overtaken by such a compulsion to consume peanut while flying that they lose sight of all other priorities?
That they are unable to stop using their peanut  the one dragon they can't put to sleep  to create a sense of pleasure and comfort?
These sound like essential symptoms of disordered eating and addiction, which, in all likelihood, derive from some longstanding issues.
The remedy is to avoid the substance in question.... "just say 'no'" ? to your peanuts.
Serving/eating peanuts on airplanes has risen to the level of a public health menace, as had tobacco smoking.
Again, the only prudent course of action is to require that distribution of peanut on airplanes be discontinued."
 < this message is answering to > 
howie: "Mulder is right on point.
Most food allergies are completely imagined.
An overly anxious parent gets it in her head that little jimmy might have had a hive after someone had peanuts in his vicinity,
and now he's "deathly allergic".
Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from peanuts (other than by choking on them)?
I sincerely doubt it.
Peanuts are incredibly nutritious,
almost universally enjoyed,
and quite filling in a small serving.
Simply put, pound for pound there is no better food on the planet.
This whole antipeanut hysteria is ridiculous!
Leave my peanuts alone!
If you are one of the incredibly rare people that have an actual medically diagnosed severe allergy to this wonderful food, then you better never leave the house because peanuts are everywhere.
You certainly should not be flying."

cqs.cq: If the overwhelming majority of people who claim to be severely allergic to peanuts are actually not medically diagnosed, then why should their unsubstantiated claims of peanut allergy be enough to justify restrictions on peanut distribution on airplanes?

Can you provide evidence from reputable medical sources that support the claim that peanuts are "almost universally enjoyed" when, in reality, many people have severe and potentially life-threatening allergies to peanuts?
If peanuts are indeed so nutritious and universally enjoyed, wouldn't the risks associated with their consumption on airplanes be outweighed by their benefits?
If the peanut allergy is indeed a negligible concern, then why do the strict regulations surrounding peanuts on airplanes seem to be an overreaction rather than a well-balanced approach?

Bill_106.input:
Bill: "I run a retail business.
If I changed my prices every few minutes or hours like the airline does or charge my customers different prices on the same day.
They would probably never come back and call the better business bureau.
And they wonder why so much distrust and angry customers.
Recently I wrote to one airline that had a ticket price of around $198. but then listed the taxes at something like $400.00 extra.
I told them it was Bait and Add on.
Similar to some retail stores that Bait customers with low price and then Switch to higher priced goods.
It is illegal and called Bait and Switch.
The airlines or some ticket sellers are guilty of lies.
Taxes are never higher than the price of the ticket.
I spend hours trying to buy a ticket without getting ripped off.
It should not be this difficult.
And one way fare should be half of a RT not higher than RT.
hey force us to buy RT and then use only the one way portion."

cqs.cq: If the airlines' practice of listing separate prices for the ticket and taxes leads to consumer distrust and anger, does this not imply that the airline's pricing strategy is indeed akin to "bait and switch"?
Do you consider the airline's practice of separating ticket price from taxes as an instance of Bait and Switch, which you claim is illegal, or is it a legitimate way to disclose additional fees?
Does the airline's practice of initially offering a lower ticket price and then adding excessive taxes not constitute a form of bait and switch, which is a deceptive business practice?
If airlines are engaging in deceptive pricing practices like bait and switch, shouldn't they be held accountable for the erosion of consumer trust and the subsequent anger towards the industry?

CF_29.input:
CF: "Yes, but what I'm saying is we shouldn’t encourage it for ourselves either
That’s my point.
And then finally, if I could just ask you, there’s a danger I think when you kind of say, “The poor are the ones who suffer. The rich are the bad guys.”
It is the case that some of the greatest examples of social progress over the years have come from well-off rich people, banks and so on, investing productively
Isn’t the problem that the only thing the banks have done is kind of consumer credit?
What they should have been doing, what they could be doing, and what they haven’t got the nerve to do, is not loaning enough
They should actually be taking more risk and giving more money out"

cqs.cq: What if the emphasis on the role of wealthy individuals in driving social progress ignores the potential consequences of their influence on economic inequality and social injustices?
Do you have a concrete example of a wealthy individual or institution that has made a significant positive impact through risk-taking and philanthropic lending, rather than solely consumer credit?

Doesn't the emphasis on individual responsibility and personal initiative from the wealthy ignore the systemic inequalities and structural barriers that prevent the poor from accessing the same opportunities and resources?
Isn't it contradictory to claim that the wealthy are the driving force behind social progress when their actions primarily revolve around consumer credit rather than productive investments?

CF_46.input:
CF: "Yes, but I'm suggesting that that was a political strategy, a way of covering things up
All I'm saying is that I think the people who took the sub-prime mortgages were the beneficiaries – and now the sufferers – of what I was saying is a policy
When you think about it now, I actually find it frustrating when I'm trying to talk to people about the real state the economy is in
And people sort of assume like everything can just carry on, and all that you need is a kind of credit based consumer thing
“Well, do we have to have cuts? Do we have to have this? Do we have to have that?”
And you do actually want to say, “Money doesn’t grow on trees.”"

cqs.cq: Do the beneficiaries of the policy, who were also the primary consumers of the sub-prime mortgages, have a moral obligation to accept responsibility for their role in the economic crisis?
Do you have any empirical evidence to support the claim that a political strategy to conceal the true state of the economy was the primary driver of the sub-prime mortgage crisis?

If the economic policies that benefited the white population were a deliberate strategy to maintain power and control, why would the consequences of those policies, such as the sub-prime mortgage crisis, not be seen as a deliberate act of systemic racism?
If politicians use policies to cover up their actions, doesn't that undermine the transparency and accountability that are supposed to be the foundation of a healthy democracy?

CLINTON_103.input:
CLINTON: "I think you 've seen another example of bait-and- switch here
For 40 years , everyone running for president has released their tax returns
You can go and see nearly , I think , 39 , 40 years of our tax returns
everyone has done it
We know the IRS has made clear there is no prohibition on releasing it when you 're under audit
you 've got to ask yourself , why wo n't he release his tax returns ?
there may be a couple of reasons
First , maybe he 's not as rich as he says he is
Second , maybe he 's not as charitable as he claims to be
maybe he does n't want the American people , all of you watching tonight , to know that he 's paid nothing in federal taxes
the only years that anybody 's ever seen were a couple of years when he had to turn them over to state authorities when he was trying to get a casino license
they showed he did n't pay any federal income tax"

cqs.cq: Would the potential concealment of his tax returns cause the public to question the authenticity of his claims about his financial and charitable contributions?
Does the lack of release of Donald Trump's tax returns for the majority of his years in office raise suspicions about his claimed wealth and charitable contributions?

If releasing tax returns for 39 years is a standard practice for presidential candidates, would it not be a reasonable expectation for a candidate to provide a full and transparent record of their tax history, rather than selectively releasing only certain years?

If he has consistently released his tax returns for 40 years, why is it unreasonable to expect him to continue this tradition of transparency now, rather than hiding behind a lack of obligation when under audit?

CLINTON_123_1.input:
CLINTON: "Race remains a significant challenge in our country
Unfortunately, race still determines too much
often determines where people live
determines what kind of education in their public schools they can get,
it determines how they're treated in the criminal justice system
We've just seen those two tragic examples in both Tulsa and Charlotte
we've got to do several things at the same time
We have to restore trust between communities and the police
We have to work to make sure that our police are using the best training, the best techniques, that they're well prepared to use force only when necessary
Everyone should be respected by the law, and everyone should respect the law
Right now, that's not the case in a lot of our neighborhoods
I have, ever since the first day of my campaign, called for criminal justice reform"

cqs.cq: Does the lack of trust between communities and the police not cause more crime and violence in the areas where police are poorly trained and prepared to use force?

Do you have any concrete, data-driven examples to support the claim that the disparities in treatment within the criminal justice system are solely attributed to racial factors, rather than other underlying social or economic factors?

If the concept of systemic racism is acknowledged as a persistent issue, would it not be accurate to assume that racial disparities in education, treatment by law enforcement, and access to justice are not solely the result of individual failures, but rather a product of a broader societal problem?
If racial disparities in treatment and opportunities are so prevalent, does the current state of law enforcement not inherently perpetuate systemic racism?

CLINTON_123_2.input:
CLINTON: "I've laid out a platform that I think would begin to remedy some of the problems we have in the criminal justice system
we also have to recognize, in addition to the challenges that we face with policing, there are so many good, brave police officers who equally want reform
we have to bring communities together in order to begin working on that as a mutual goal
we've got to get guns out of the hands of people who should not have them
The gun epidemic is the leading cause of death of young African- American men, more than the next nine causes put together
we have to do two things
We have to restore trust
We have to work with the police
We have to make sure they respect the communities and the communities respect them
we have to tackle the plague of gun violence
which is a big contributor to a lot of the problems that we're seeing today"

cqs.cq: If the gun epidemic is the leading cause of death of young African-American men, more than the next nine causes put together, does this suggest that addressing gun violence should be a priority over other social issues in the criminal justice system?
Do you have any evidence that the gun epidemic is indeed the leading cause of death of young African-American men, surpassing the next nine causes combined, as claimed by you?

If the police officers who Clinton acknowledges as "good and brave" are part of the institution that disproportionately affects African-American communities, why should their efforts towards reform be considered a reason to trust that institution?

If we're prioritizing restoring trust between law enforcement and communities, doesn't that imply that the problem of police brutality and systemic racism is a major concern, rather than just a matter of community outreach?

CLINTON_130_1.input:
CLINTON: "I've heard Donald say this at his rallies
it's really unfortunate that he paints such a dire negative picture of black communities in our country
the vibrancy of the black church
the black businesses that employ so many people
the opportunities that so many families are working to provide for their kids
There's a lot that we should be proud of and we should be supporting and lifting up
we do always have to make sure we keep people safe
There are the right ways of doing it
then there are ways that are ineffective
Stop-and-frisk was found to be unconstitutional
in part, because it was ineffective
It did not do what it needed to do
I believe in community policing
in fact, violent crime is one-half of what it was in 1991
Property crime is down 40 percent
We just don't want to see it creep back up
We've had 25 years of very good cooperation
there were some problems
some unintended consequences
Too many young African-American and Latino men ended up in jail for nonviolent offenses"

cqs.cq: Does the fact that stop-and-frisk was found to be unconstitutional because of its ineffectiveness imply that the effectiveness of community policing depends on its implementation rather than its principles?

Does the efficacy of community policing in reducing crime, as demonstrated by the 50% decrease in violent crime and 40% decrease in property crime, outweigh the concerns about the potential for racial profiling and the disproportionate impact on minority communities?

If the Clinton administration acknowledges that stop-and-frisk was ineffective and unconstitutional, why does she not also acknowledge that the very same tactics of racial profiling and policing that were found to be ineffective and unconstitutional are still being applied in other forms, such as through her own comments on the "vibrancy of the black church" and "black businesses"?
If Mr. Trump's negative portrayal of black communities is indeed unfortunate, then shouldn't he be held accountable for the potential harm caused by his rhetoric?

CLINTON_130_2.input:
CLINTON: "it's just a fact that if you're a young African-American man and you do the same thing as a young white man, you are more likely to be arrested, charged, convicted, and incarcerated
we've got to address the systemic racism in our criminal justice system
We cannot just say law and order
we have to come forward with a plan that is going to divert people from the criminal justice system
deal with mandatory minimum sentences, which have put too many people away for too long for doing too little
We need to have more second chance programs
I'm glad that we're ending private prisons in the federal system
I want to see them ended in the state system
You shouldn't have a profit motivation to fill prison cells with young Americans
here are some positive ways we can work on this
I believe strongly that commonsense gun safety measures would assist us
Right now—and this is something Donald has supported, along with the gun lobby—right now, we've got too many military- style weapons on the streets
this is something Donald has supported, along with the gun lobby
In a lot of places, our police are outgunned
We need comprehensive background checks
we need to keep guns out of the hands of those who will do harm
we finally need to pass a prohibition on anyone who's on the terrorist watch list from being able to buy a gun in our country
If you're too dangerous to fly, you are too dangerous to buy a gun
there are things we can do
we ought to do it in a bipartisan way"

cqs.cq: Would the absence of comprehensive background checks cause the proliferation of guns in the hands of those who would do harm?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that a bipartisan approach is more effective in addressing systemic racism in the criminal justice system than a solely partisan approach?
If the system disproportionately criminalizes young African-American men, does that not imply that the systemic racism in our criminal justice system is perpetuating a cycle of systemic oppression?

If we acknowledge that systemic racism affects the likelihood of arrest, conviction, and incarceration for young African-American men, then how can we justify the continued use of mandatory minimum sentences that disproportionately impact minority communities?

CLINTON_147.input:
CLINTON: "New York has done an excellent job
I give credit across the board going back two mayors, two police chiefs
it has worked
other communities need to come together to do what will work
one murder is too many
it is important that we learn about what has been effective
not go to things that sound good that really did not have the kind of impact that we would want
Who disagrees with keeping neighborhoods safe
no one should disagree about respecting the rights of young men who live in those neighborhoods
we need to do a better job of working, again, with the communities, faith communities, business communities, as well as the police to try to deal with this problem"

cqs.cq: What if the community's lack of collaboration and coordination with law enforcement, as emphasized by Mayor Clinton, ends up causing a decrease in crime rates?
Does the Mayor of New York City's approach to addressing crime, as described by Clinton, align with the views of law enforcement experts who have been critical of the city's policing strategies?

If New York has effectively reduced crime and improved neighborhood safety by working with communities, would that same collaborative approach not be effective in addressing other social issues, like poverty and education, that disproportionately affect minority communities?

If New York has indeed done an excellent job in keeping neighborhoods safe, then why should we not expect the same level of success from other communities, considering the resources and expertise are presumably similar?

CLINTON_17.input:
CLINTON: "let 's stop for a second and remember where we were eight years ago
We had the worst financial crisis , the Great Recession
the worst since the 1930s
 slashed taxes on the wealthy
failed to invest in the middle class
took their eyes off of Wall Street
created a perfect storm
was in large part because of tax policies
Donald was one of the people who rooted for the housing crisis
...
 it did collapse"

cqs.cq: Does the tax policies of the past contribute to the economic instability that led to the Great Recession?
Can you provide a specific example of a policy or action taken by President Clinton during his presidency that directly contributed to the economic growth and recovery following the Great Recession?
If the wealthy were held accountable for their actions during the 2008 financial crisis, why should they not be held accountable for the consequences of their policies?

If the wealthy's tax cuts contributed to the Great Recession, then how does the current administration's plan to further reduce their tax burden align with the goal of preventing future economic crises?

CLINTON_176_1.input:
CLINTON: "cyber security, cyber warfare will be one of the biggest challenges facing the next president
clearly we're facing at this point two different kinds of adversaries
There are the independent hacking groups that do it mostly for commercial reasons to try to steal information that they can use to make money
increasingly, we are seeing cyber attacks coming from states, organs of states
The most recent and troubling of these has been Russia
There's no doubt now that Russia has used cyber attacks against all kinds of organizations in our country
I am deeply concerned about this
Donald's very praiseworthy of Vladimir Putin
Putin is playing a really tough, long game here
one of the things he's done is to let loose cyber attackers to hack into government files, to hack into personal files, hack into the Democratic National Committee"

cqs.cq: Does the Russian president's endorsement of Donald's presidency and his own history of cyber attacks make him a less trustworthy ally in the fight against cyber threats?
Do you believe that the United States should prioritize strengthening its cybersecurity measures, given the evident threat posed by state-sponsored cyber attacks, such as those attributed to Russia?

aimwill_178.input:

annoyed_177.input:

 < this message is answering to > 
citizen-s: "I strongly support cash compensation for bumping passengers with zeroprice tickets,
But to assure adequate compensation and prevent airlines gaming such a requirement,
compensation should be at the average (cash) ticket price for that service class on that flight.
DOT's proposed rule using the lowest fare ticket would encourage airlines to bump those with zeroprice tickets first,
since that cost would be lowest.

The growing scarcity of actual seats for miles
something that cries out for regulatory intervention

cqs.cq: Does the lack of a clear formula for overbooking directly affect the likelihood of bumping passengers with zero-fare tickets?

cd38_220_1.input:
cd38: "As someone who carries an epipen for beestings,

several posts mention the risk inherent in many people opening bags of peanuts at one time
(which can easily happen when snacks are served)
throwing a large amount of dust in the air,
which could be enough to trigger an allergy in severely allergic people.
However, banning people from carrying on their own snacks does seem to violate their rights,
to eliminate what seems like an extremely small risk to allergysufferers.
Nuts are a healthy, portable form of protein,

but, I'm a vegetarian,
and  I fly constantly, often on longhaul international flights, but mainly between the east and west coasts,"

cqs.cq: What if the ban on carrying peanuts on flights causes allergic reactions to manifest and affect the overall passenger experience?

cd38_220_2.input:
cd38: "The return flight is 6 ½ hours (plus commute time to the airport);
when time allows, I make something to bring on the flight,
but if my mother is having a bad day, that's not always possible.
On a recent trip, I didn't have time to eat anything at all the day I flew home; got stuck in traffic and barely made my flight (I was the last one on) so didn't have time to eat or buy anything at the airport; and as we started to taxi, the flight crew announced that we had a nut allergy on board, and that they (JB) would not be serving cashews and requested that we not eat any nuts we may have brought on board.
6 ½ hours feels pretty long at that point!
No, it didn't kill me,
but it does seem that if JB hadn't served cashews, the risks involved in one or two people eating nuts they may have brought with them would have been extremely, extremely small....
and, NOTHING in life is riskfree.
I understand that people want to minimize the risks for their loved ones,
but you cannot eliminate the risk completely, regardless of what legislation you put in place.
If I ate peanuts at the airport, didn't wash my hands, and then opened the rest room door on the plane immediately before a peanut allergy sufferer, that person could suffer a reaction.
I can support airlines not serving peanuts/peanut products,
thereby eliminating the most likely possible cause of a peanutrelated incident on a flight;
but not restrictions on what people may choose to eat."

cqs.cq: Would the potential risks of peanut-related incidents on a flight be significantly mitigated if airlines only served peanuts in designated nut-free zones, rather than having a complete ban on peanuts?
