If airlines can minimize risks by not serving peanuts, why can't they also minimize the risks by not allowing passengers to bring peanuts on board?

citizen-s_134.input:
citizen-s: "DOT's objective in setting this rule should be to ELIMINATE all bumping, not merely achieve some (unspecified) reduction.
Regardless of how many caveats an airline might state in its contract terms, passengers neither want nor deserve a ticket for an oversold seat.
Bumping is a purely economic device that treats passengers as economic units devoid of humanity, like so many other aspects of airline behavior.
From that objective, it follows that there should be NO cap on compensation
and that the financial penalty to the airline should be strong enough to prevent bumping, not just keep it at some arbitrarily "acceptable" level.
The 100% of the total ticket price for expected arrival within 2 hours later is reasonable.
Compensation for a longer delay should be the GREATER of 200% of the total ticket cost or the passenger's demonstrable outofpocket costs resulting from the delay
(a) including any higher priced air ticket from the same or another carrier at the same class, and lodging, meals and incidentals at average prevailing prices in that metro area,
and (b) with the obligation on the passenger to minimize those costs by arranging, with good faith help from the airline, an alternate flight or other means to get him or her to the destination as soon as reasonably practical."

cqs.cq: If DOT's objective is to eliminate all bumping, then why would the proposed 100% of the total ticket price compensation for expected arrival within 2 hours be insufficient to deter airlines from bumping passengers?

Do you have any expert opinion from a reputable aviation or consumer rights organization that supports the claim that airlines should be allowed to maintain a cap on compensation for bumping, rather than offering full or 200% reimbursement?

If airlines can treat passengers as economic units devoid of humanity, why should the value of a passenger's time and out-of-pocket expenses be limited to a fixed percentage of the ticket price rather than being calculated based on the actual impact of the delay?

If bumping is a purely economic device that treats passengers as economic units devoid of humanity, does the airline's objective of merely reducing bumping rather than eliminating it not inherently undermine the very principle of treating passengers as human beings?

It is not just the five hours, though that is bad enough; it is all the other inconveniences, arriving late at night, having to cancel engagements, having to call a cab for a long ride vs bus transportation, and a myriad other inconveniences for which the airlines in their hubris currently accepts no responsibility."
 < this message is answering to > 
drgreg: "I believe airlines should be forced to fully reimburse confirmed passengers whenever the airline changes flight schedules after booking.
I frequently reserve flights up to one year in advance, in order to secure the lowest price and best seat.
I do this even though the airline will charge me $150 (plus fare difference) to change my itinerary for personal reasons once booked.
However, the airline frequently change flight schedules for confirmed passengers without compensation, nor consideration of passengers' plans.
For example, a trip to Europe on United Airlines has now been changed 7 times by the airline since I confirmed my reservation in December 2009.
The resulting changes have added nearly 5 hours to the total trip, plus I'm now required to leave at 3AM for the airport (instead of my original departure of 8AM), and I return after midnight, rather than a more reasonable 10:30PM.
In addition, United Airlines has not offered to waive the change fee, nor provide seats on alternate dates or airline partners.
If I'm required to pay exorbitant fees to the airlines to change my original itinerary, due to personal circumstances, then the airlines should also be required to compensate inconvenienced passengers in full AND provide satisfactory alternate travel arrangements comparable to the original flight schedule.
Perhaps this would force the airlines to recognize the hardships they create for passengers when schedules are revised after passengers have already received confirmed flights and make related travel arrangements."

cqs.cq: If the airlines consistently prioritize their own interests and revenue over passenger convenience and well-being, do they not bear responsibility for the resulting hardships and inconveniences caused by their schedule changes?

If airlines can charge passengers to change their itineraries for personal reasons, why should they not also be held accountable for their own schedule changes that cause passengers to incur similar inconveniences?

JJMurray_180.input:
JJMurray: "a classic example above.
Don't just ban peanuts,
ban everything that might contain something which may have encountered a peanut or peanut product in it's life.
Once you start a ban on one product, you better be prepared for more and more demands to ban a lot of other items."
 < this message is answering to > 
PracticalJo: "Take peanuts off of planes.
Safety first.
It is not only airborne particles that are problematical,
it is also the crumbs, whole peanuts that "get away" from the passenger (i.e., dropped on floor or in seat), and residue left behind on seats, seat belts, floors, tray tables and other surfaces.
Ingestion or contact can trigger severe reactions.
Take peanuts and items containing peanuts/peanut butter (e.g., trail mix, peanut butter crackers) off of airplanes.
This is all the airlines need to do.
Most airlines already have a suitable replacement snack.
Anyone with a severe allergy already has EpiPens or other medications.
Airlines need not provide these.
As an outsider to the airline industry, it is hard for me to say what level of cleaning currently occurs on an aircraft.
Obviously, on quick turnaround layovers, flight crews only have time for a cursory cleaning.
I don't know.
If so, perhaps repeated standard cleanings without further peanut exposure would be sufficient?
The rule probably has the best chance of being enacted if it minimizes overall cost to the airline industry while meeting the desired safety requirements.
Personally, I would be satisfied if the rule simply called for removal of peanuts from aircraft and allowed the airlines to put forth a good faith effort at cleaning their fleets."

cqs.cq: Would the removal of peanuts from aircraft be an effective cause in reducing the risk of severe allergic reactions among passengers, or would it simply be a precursor to further demands for banning other food items?
Do you believe that the potential health risks associated with peanut exposure on airplanes outweigh the potential economic costs and practical challenges of implementing a comprehensive peanut ban?
If airlines can take steps to minimize peanut exposure through repeated standard cleanings, why should the ban on peanuts be absolute and not allow for a good faith effort at cleaning their fleets?

If the goal is to ensure passenger safety, why would the airlines' current cursory cleaning procedures, which may not completely eliminate peanut exposure, be considered sufficient when a more thorough cleaning process could be implemented to minimize the risk?

JL_3.input:

cqs.cq: Does the varying interest rate not cause the cost of borrowing to be directly influenced by the repayment period?

JL_5.input:

if you borrowed £200 from me, and in 30 days time you pay back £250, the interest rate on that is 1,413.01%

...

cqs.cq: What if the difference in interest rates is so significant that it causes borrowers to be incentivized to delay repayment, potentially affecting the overall financial health of the individuals and the economy?

JW_41.input:
JW: "It’s only since the state intervened that people have been uninterested in which bank they put their money in

This stopped not because of the big bang, which liberalised banking, which is what everybody thinks.
It stopped because of government guarantees to depositors."

cqs.cq: Would the government's guarantees to depositors indeed be the primary reason behind the decline of prudent behavior in bankers, rather than the liberalization of banking itself?
Do you have a historical example of a period where banks were indeed prudent and advertising their prudence without government guarantees to depositors?

If the prudent behavior of early bankers was solely driven by the absence of government guarantees, would their actions not be similarly driven by the absence of government guarantees in the present day?
Wouldn't the elimination of government guarantees have led to a more prudent banking system, rather than the reckless behavior that exists today?

Javier_84.input:
Javier: "I have no problem requiring the airlines to give notification of any "known" delays within 30 minutes of when they become aware of it.
BUT, being a frequent traveler, I see all sorts of problems which are unavoidable and for which the airlines will be blamed by giving such notice with the intend that some flyers may be able to delay thier trip to the airport or even the departure gate.
I know that many times the airlines can't also know exactly when a weather hold or a maintenance issue will be rectified and that the flight is then ready to go.
Many time it can be surprisingly faster than expected.
The problem is that some flyers may then  wait before going to the airport,
but then find that the problem was rectified sooner than expected and the flight departed.
Of course the flyer and the flyers rights organization will then crucify the airlines for such poor planning.
Flyers need to grow up and quit pouting and blaming everthing on the airlines.
They can't have it both ways."

cqs.cq: Would requiring airlines to provide 30-minute notifications for unavoidable delays cause flyers to become overly reliant on such notifications and then feel justified in delaying their travel, rather than learning to adapt to the unpredictability of flight schedules?

Do you have any evidence to support the claim that flyers are not responsible for their own time management and should not be held accountable for delays that may arise from unavoidable circumstances?

If airlines are held accountable for delays they cannot accurately predict, should passengers be expected to hold airlines accountable for being too optimistic when predicting delays that ultimately get resolved sooner than expected?
If airlines are expected to notify passengers of delays, shouldn't they also be held accountable for not providing timely updates when the flight is unexpectedly back on schedule?

JetJock_156_1.input:
JetJock: "Yes, most airlines pay flight crew members scheduled flight time or actual time away from the gate whichever is more.
Eg. if a flight is scheduled for 2 hours "block to block" (from/to the gate) but it takes 3 to fly it, the crew gets 3.
If the flight leaves that gate and returns 2.5 hours later, most airlines only pay that crew either the 2.0 scheduled (if it cancels) or much less.
For most crewmembers, the notion that 1 hour at the gate, 2.5 hours of sitting on that taxiway and only get paid for 2 is not very palatable.
Whereas sitting for 2.5 hours then fly 2 totals 4.5.
It is mostly the pay structure of pilots/flight attendants that poorly designed.
Most people would balk at the notion of working 4.5 hours and getting paid for 2.
The ground delay limitation, has, well, it's limitations."

cqs.cq: Does the flawed pay structure for flight crew members cause them to feel underpaid and undervalued, leading to potential job dissatisfaction and turnover?

Do you have any empirical evidence or industry data to support the claim that most airlines' pay structures for flight crew members are poorly designed, rather than a neutral or well-structured compensation system?

If a pilot or flight attendant is paid for actual flight time, why would they not be compensated for the time spent waiting at the gate, potentially exceeding the scheduled time, just as they are compensated for the actual flight time?
If airlines pay crew members for the scheduled flight time, why do they not also compensate them for the extra time spent waiting on the taxiway, thereby acknowledging the value of their time?

JetJock_156_2.input:
JetJock: "If we were in preregulation days where an airline was making money with only 60% of the seats filled, flights canceling due to the 3 hour limit would not be much of a problem.
What is a problem is flights that are now being canceled because of the new rule
and virtually no seats available on subsequent flights to accommodate those passengers.
If the ground delays are due to ATC, weather, VIP movement (president in the area) then passengers will not be, as a rule, given cancellation perks since they are beyond the control of the company.
If the air conditioning, and restrooms are functioning properly and there are plenty of beverages and snacks on board then that maximum number of hours should be flexible.
I would be curious to hear from people that had their flight cancel due to the 3 hour limit and how the airlines handled them after that.
My guess this rule will cause greater damage to air travel then the occasional extended ground hold on an airplane with poor air conditioning or nonfunctioning lavatories.
if the airplane is comfortable and exceeding the 3 hour limit would cancel the flight with no hotel or meal compensation, would exceeding the 3 hours be ok and if so what would be a reasonable number above 3 be?"

cqs.cq: Would the increased cancellations due to the 3 hour limit cause a ripple effect that ultimately lead to a decrease in airline revenue, or would the airline's ability to compensate passengers for cancellations and delays outweigh the costs associated with the rule?

Do you have any evidence or expert opinion that supports the claim that airlines would be justified in canceling flights due to the 3 hour limit without offering any compensation to passengers, despite the presence of basic amenities and services on board?
Would the airlines' ability to cancel flights due to the 3-hour limit be a more significant problem than the occasional inconveniences caused by ground delays, VIP movement, or mechanical issues?
Is the airline's profit motive and efficiency more important than passenger comfort and well-being, especially when the airline has the resources to provide a comfortable in-flight experience?

KHenrickson_172.input:
KHenrickson: "The notification isn't so much a problem at most airports.
The electronic boards are usually updated minute by minute.
The problem is that the airlines will say "Flight 100, delayed till 7:00pm." then "Flight 100, delayed till 7:05pm".  And so on and so forth.
They're notifying everyone...with completely useless information.
Forcing them to do so more frequently isn't going to fix a thing.
Forcing them to come up with an accurate estimate is what is needed."

cqs.cq: Wouldn't the constant updates of flight delays by the airlines ultimately cause confusion and frustration among passengers, rather than providing any useful information?

Do you have any evidence from airlines or industry experts that suggests that updating flight information every minute is a more effective way to manage passenger expectations than providing accurate and timely estimates?
Would the constant minute-by-minute updates by airlines be more comparable to a doctor repeatedly telling a patient their condition is still the same, rather than providing an accurate diagnosis?

If the primary issue with airport notifications is providing inaccurate information, shouldn't airlines be held accountable for their lack of accuracy rather than being forced to update their boards more frequently?

MP_22.input:
MP: "Well, you say the banks are the lenders
there are lots of other people who are lenders too
I mean everyone who puts money into a bank, or a building society, is putting it there so that the bank can lend it on
I mean you just heard Simon Rose say
there’s been 100 billion pounds transfer from savers to borrowers
So if you're going to raise your banner for anybody who’s doing badly in this situation, I would have thought you might have raised it for savers, in the first instance"

cqs.cq: If banks are indeed the lenders, then why are the savers, who are also lenders, being blamed for the banks' lending practices rather than the banks themselves?
Do you have any empirical evidence that the collective losses of savers, as mentioned by Simon Rose, are indeed greater than the losses of borrowers?
If the banks are indeed lenders, wouldn't the savers who put their money into banks also be considered lenders, thus deserving similar consideration in this situation?

If everyone who puts money into a bank is a lender, then shouldn't the MP also be raising concerns about the borrowers, who are also contributing to the 100 billion pounds transfer, rather than just focusing on the banks?

MP_48.input:
MP: "	I think it’s very interesting that capitalism is coming under such a lot of attack here
And I don’t say that’s inappropriate
But we haven’t yet attacked democracy
I mean one of the things that strikes me about this is that when you have incumbent governments, and they see that consumer credit boom mushrooming and mushrooming, what do they do?
They don’t want to stop it
They don’t want to stop it, because they want voters.
They want voters who feel artificially rich
because voters who feel artificially rich will probably vote for the incumbent"

cqs.cq: Does the desire to maintain a consumer credit boom serve as a cause that leads to a political effect of prioritizing short-term voter benefits over long-term economic stability?

Do you believe that the notion that voters who feel artificially rich are more likely to vote for the incumbent is a sufficient explanation for the government's reluctance to regulate consumer credit, or is there another factor at play?

If voters who feel artificially rich are more likely to vote for the incumbent, does this not imply that the incumbent is more accountable to the interests of the wealthy rather than the broader population?

If politicians are indeed concerned about voters who feel artificially rich, then don't they have a responsibility to address the root causes of economic inequality rather than just manipulating consumer credit to serve their own interests?

MR_TELEVOID__178.input:
MR: "Maybe you're just the only one who gives a shit about their hair"
 < this message is answering to > 
XxEnder: "Am I the only one who noticed that Bernie combed his hair"

cqs.cq: Does the fact that XxEnder noticed Bernie's hair suggest that his hair is a significant aspect of his public image?
Do you have a specific reference to a study or expert opinion that supports the claim that hair grooming habits are a notable aspect of a person's character?
If a politician's hairstyle choice is considered a legitimate aspect of their character, why is a person's natural hair texture or style seen as irrelevant to their professional qualifications?
Is it not ironic that you're fixating on Bernie's hair when the statement itself implies that you're the only one who cares about it?

MT_10.input:
MT: "we know from lots and lots of research, you know this, that people aren’t very good at understanding financial products
And they're easily seduced into acting, in the short-term, in ways which aren’t very good for them in the long-term
Doesn’t the history of the financial services industry demonstrate that this is an industry with a deep commitment to exploiting those weaknesses, in order to make a fast buck?"

cqs.cq: Does the exploitation of consumers' financial illiteracy by the financial services industry lead to widespread financial instability among the population?
Does the financial services industry's history of prioritizing short-term gains over long-term consumer well-being not reflect a fundamentally exploitative business model?
Does the financial services industry's history of exploiting consumer weaknesses equate to a predatory relationship?
Does the exploitation of consumer weaknesses by the financial services industry justify the need for regulatory measures to protect consumers from long-term financial harm?

MT_40.input:
MT: "I don’t think you just said the opposite of them was neutral
So if they're virtues, doesn’t that imply that the opposite of thrift and prudence is immoral?
But, hold on
Isn’t it simply the case that buying a cup of coffee is something which is substantially less demanding than working up a long-term interest rate?
Therefore isn’t it a reasonable thing for the state to intervene in those cases
because the knowledge is bounded?"

cqs.cq: Does the state's intervention in economic decisions, such as buying a cup of coffee, not undermine the virtues of thrift and prudence?
Does your reasoning that the state should intervene in cases where the knowledge is bounded imply that virtue is inherently relative rather than absolute?
Is the virtue of thrift and prudence in the context of financial decisions equivalent to a moral virtue in other aspects of life?
Doesn't the state's intervention in economic matters imply that virtues like thrift and prudence are not absolute, but rather context-dependent?

Melanie_64.input:
Melanie: "Well the State has taken a moral position
that position was non-judgmentalism
and terrible harm it’s done
It’s created a lot of victims who now need help themselves, and who sometimes go on to create other victims through crime
 I think they do need help
but that help should be very carefully calibrated, to restore the capacity for independence and personal responsibility"

cqs.cq: Does the State's non-judgmental approach towards those who have been harmed actually cause more harm by enabling the creation of additional victims through crime rather than promoting true rehabilitation and personal responsibility?
Do you believe the State's non-judgmental approach to crime has indeed led to a significant increase in victimization, as you claim, or is this a subjective interpretation of its effects?
If the State's moral position is non-judgmentalism, does that not imply a responsibility to provide support to victims without prioritizing punishment over rehabilitation?
If the State's non-judgmentalism stance is meant to promote rehabilitation and restoration, does that not also imply a responsibility to hold perpetrators accountable for their actions?

Mpogoda_184.input:
Mpogoda: "As a frequent traveler, I would welcome the rule requiring 24 hour refundability of fares + all fees.
Additionally, there should be a certain window,
say, 3 days prior to flying where you should be able to cancel your flight without penalty and receive a refund or at least the ability to change your itinerary without fee.
As I always say to all who will listen,
the airline model is one of the worst business models I know of:
treat your customers with disdain and make it as inconvenient as possible for them to use your product.
Whether it be added fees to check luggage
making it too costly to change your itinerary;
making it virtually impossible to easily use frequent flyer miles or charging an exorbitant amount to actually use them;
not getting timely notice when there are delays to flights
or, even worse, when a flight has been canceled;
and lastly, being treated like cattle at the airport and on the plane."

cqs.cq: Would the airline's business model be more customer-centric if they were held accountable for the consequences of their actions, such as lost revenue due to frequent cancellations and refunds?
Do you have any evidence that airlines are intentionally designing their policies to treat customers with disdain, rather than simply being driven by neutral business decisions?
If airlines can profit from charging customers for the privilege of changing flights, would they not also benefit from offering a 24-hour refund policy to maintain customer loyalty and trust?
If the airline model is indeed one of the worst, does this justify the industry's expectation of consumers to be flexible and accommodating in the face of cancellations and delays?

MrFordization__82.input:
MrFordization: "Pentagon classifies global warming as a national security threat
Maybe he just knows more than you"

cqs.cq: Does the Pentagon's classification of global warming as a national security threat imply that the consequences of climate change will cause a decline in national defense capabilities?
Do you have a credible source that supports the claim that Mr. Ford's personal opinions or experiences justify the Pentagon's classification of global warming as a national security threat?

If the Pentagon classifies global warming as a national security threat, does that imply that the U.S. government should prioritize the long-term consequences of climate change over short-term economic gains?
If the Pentagon classifies global warming as a national security threat, does this not imply that the impact of climate change is more of a threat to the country than the actions of other nations?

Mulder_112.input:
Mulder: "Your argument is a strawman.
Nobody is advocating funerals;
you're just trying to deflect attention away from the issue,
which is that there is no real risk to peanut allergy sufferers.
And there is no scientific evidence to support your argument.
You can't even cite the studies you claim exist,
because they don't exist.
The only mean spirited people are those like yourself, who want to trample the rights of the majority for a nonexistent risk that affects a very small number of people.
This has nothing to do with the founding of the U.S. at all."

cqs.cq: Does the lack of scientific evidence supporting the argument about peanut allergy risks justify the potential infringement of rights of the majority?

Can you provide a single scientific study that supports the claim that peanut allergy sufferers are at a significant risk to the point of warranting the removal of the right to sue for damages from the majority?

If the lack of scientific evidence and the absence of cited studies to support a claim are enough to discredit an argument, why should the lack of scientific evidence and the absence of cited studies to support the claim that there is no risk to peanut allergy sufferers be ignored in this debate?
If the argument that peanut allergy sufferers are at a significant risk is a strawman, then why is there no evidence to support the claim that it poses a substantial threat to public health?

Mulder_226.input:
Mulder: "Apparently Samsmom is the ignorant one.
She attacks what she clearly does not understand.
If her child has a true peanut allergy that is so severe, he shouldn't be flying,
since her argument is that any contact with peanut dust or oil would cause anaphylactic shock.
Since that possibility is very real even outside an airline cabin,
she's making her own argument for living in a bubble.
Facts are stubborn things,
and one of those facts is that the air onboard an airliner is cleaner than in most public buildings,
so there's very little, if any, real risk involved in flying on a jet where peanuts have been consumed before or are even being served now.
Another stubborn fact is that you can be desensitized to peanut allergies,
but if you're unwilling to do it, don't blame others for not bending to your petty fears.
Nobody has studied this subject,
so there's no hard data.
But we do know that the air onboard an airliner is much cleaner than people think.
Only one confirmed death onboard an airliner has been reported,
but it may have been as far back as 1998,
and it was an Eastern European airline."
 < this message is answering to > 
Samsmom: "I am utterly amazed at the ignorance displayed by some of those commenting here.
Allergies are not "perceived"
as Mulder suggests,
and it is ridiculous and unrealistic  to suggest that people with severe food allergies "live in a bubble".
No one who has an allergy chooses to be in this situation,
and walking onto an airplane where peanuts either are being consumed or have been consumed is like playing Russian Roulette.
We are talking about a SNACK ON AN AIRPLANE.
Can you really be complaining about your rights to eat a snack?!?
My son could DIE because you can't forgo a snack for two hours.
While we could drive everywhere we need to go for the rest of his life,
there may come a time when time constraints force us to fly.
No matter how much "responsibility we take", we cannot sufficiently protect him if people around us are eating any peanut product.
We always carry an epipen,
and feel that should be our responsibility.
But, again, that may not be enough to save his life.
Those autoinjectors can only buy us 1015 minutes,
barely enough time for a plane to request an emergency landing site.
He would be dead before we taxied to the gate.
FOR A SNACK!!
An outright ban should be in place."

cqs.cq: Does the fact that the airline industry has a history of implementing safety measures, such as restrictions on smoking, and the presence of anaphylactic shock being a rare occurrence, outweigh the concerns of parents like Samsmom who are advocating for a blanket ban on peanuts in-flight?

Do you have any credible evidence to support the claim that the risk of anaphylactic shock from peanut dust or oil in an airline cabin is substantial enough to justify the outright ban of peanuts on flights?

If children with severe food allergies are deemed to require a peanut-free environment to avoid potential anaphylactic shock, why should their parents not be afforded similar accommodations to ensure their child's safety, such as a peanut-free airline policy?
Is it fair to impose the burden of constant vigilance and risk on others, rather than advocating for more comprehensive safety measures to accommodate individuals with severe food allergies?

Mulder_240.input:
Mulder: "You're the one who seems to be partisan.
Instead of thinking logically about it, you try to deflect blame for your misguided apprehension onto others by insinuating they have a compulsion.
Serving and eating peanuts is not a public health menace,
so you need to get over it.
Instead of conflating the possible with the inevitable, you should focus on the reality, which is that the possibility is extremely small.
You're more likely to die from getting hit by a car crossing the street, yet you're not advocating we ban driving.
That's being a hypocrite."
 < this message is answering to > 
Antanagoge: "Is it really possible that all blindly partisan advocates of the peanut in this context eat peanuts and only peanuts?
That they are overtaken by such a compulsion to consume peanut while flying that they lose sight of all other priorities?
That they are unable to stop using their peanut  the one dragon they can't put to sleep  to create a sense of pleasure and comfort?
These sound like essential symptoms of disordered eating and addiction, which, in all likelihood, derive from some longstanding issues.
The remedy is to avoid the substance in question.... "just say 'no'" ? to your peanuts.
Serving/eating peanuts on airplanes has risen to the level of a public health menace, as had tobacco smoking.
Again, the only prudent course of action is to require that distribution of peanut on airplanes be discontinued."

cqs.cq: Is it possible that the advocates of peanut distribution on airplanes are merely deflecting blame for their own fears by conflating the possibility of an allergy reaction with the inevitability of a public health menace?
Do you have any personal experience or scientific evidence to support the claim that peanut consumption is a public health menace comparable to tobacco smoking?

Is it plausible that the same advocates who claim to be concerned about public health issues would not be more vocal about the actual risks associated with peanuts on airplanes if they were truly driven by a desire to protect public health?

If serving/eating peanuts on airplanes is comparable to a public health menace, does that justify the draconian measure of banning peanut distribution on planes, while tobacco smoking, a far greater health hazard, is still permitted?

ND_28.input:
ND: "In some ways I agree with you
If you want the economy to run smoothly, you have to incentivise certain types of behaviour.
So, for example in South Korea, in terms of how South Korean grew, it did incentivise saving, at certain times, by certain economic policies
On the other hand, I think what people don’t realise, or only half realise, is the fact that we have actually written off massive amounts of debt
But it certainly isn’t the debts of the people who most need it in society
For productive investments. I agree with you."

cqs.cq: What if the economic policies that incentivise certain types of behaviour in South Korea are causing the country to write off massive amounts of debt for the people who most need it in society?

Do you believe that incentivizing certain behaviors through economic policies can be a more effective means of achieving societal goals than addressing the systemic issues of debt and economic inequality?
If South Korea's economic policies incentivized saving, why would similar policies not be applied to incentivize paying off the debts of those who most need it in society?

If incentivising certain behaviors can lead to positive outcomes, such as economic growth in South Korea, does it not follow that incentivising debt forgiveness for those who most need it could also lead to positive outcomes?

NYCMuscleman18_161.input:
NYCMuscleman18: "I know this sounds silly,
but I think I shouldn't be charged as much to check a bag as the 250lb man sitting next to me.
I don't mind getting weighed in public...
I don't know.
This is just something that seems unfair to lots of passengers,
and that probably won't get changed without regulation.
At the very least, DOT should make clear to airlines that they can discriminate on the basis of weight without fearing regulatory action."

cqs.cq: Would allowing airlines to charge passengers based on their weight, rather than their actual size, effectively cause a discriminatory pricing system that would disproportionately affect passengers of a certain size?

Do you have a scientific study or expert opinion that supports the claim that weight-based discrimination in airline fees is justified to the extent that a 250lb person should be charged more than a 250lb person?
If the airline can discriminate on the basis of weight without fear of regulatory action, why should passengers who are overweight not have the option to choose a seat with a lower weight-based fee?
Should a 250lb passenger be allowed to pay less for checking a bag than a passenger of average weight if the airline already discriminates based on weight without facing regulatory action?

NYCMuscleman18_187.input:
NYCMuscleman18: "Agreed.
The most frustrating thing about airline travel is the lack of space.
I don't see why they care so much about letting people game the bumping system, but not at all about personal space.
I guess the big question is, what's DOT's job, exactly?
Is this about inair convenience?
Avoiding pricegouging?
Or something else?"
 < this message is answering to > 
AK-traveler: "Airlines should not be allowed to charge for items necessary because of factors out of the passengers control.
Seat size and configuration (arm and leg room) should be addressed as a health issue.
The inflight magazines show exercises passengers should do at their seats to prevent deep vein thrombosis
but there isn't enough room to do them.
And finally, I think it is unfair if not criminal and discriminatory to charge exorbinant fees for carrying your pet onboard with you.
The carrier is handled as a carry on bag solely by me,
the airline doesn't do anything
yet they carage $100 or more each way."

cqs.cq: Do the airlines' prioritization of in-flight amenities and pet fees over passenger space and comfort potentially cause a significant health impact on passengers, which in turn affects their overall travel experience?
Do you consider the lack of space in airline seats a health issue that warrants regulation, or is it merely a matter of consumer convenience?

If the airline industry prioritizes passenger safety by providing exercise instructions to prevent deep vein thrombosis, why don't they also prioritize passenger comfort by providing adequate space to perform these exercises?

If passengers are considered vulnerable to deep vein thrombosis due to inadequate seat space, shouldn't airlines prioritize passenger health by providing sufficient legroom, rather than solely focusing on charging for carry-on pets?

PeanutAllergy_232.input:
PeanutAllergy: "My son is allergic to peanuts.
The last time we flew on an airline that served peanuts (Southwest) we called ahead and requested that no peanuts be served on our flight.
The airline was extremely accommodating, but there were peanuts on the floor and between the seats from earlier flights.
For that reason, I don't see banning peanuts on specific flights or a peanutfree buffer zone as real solutions.
We now only fly airlines that don't serve peanuts.
We're okay with Snickers because the peanuts are less likely to get spilled.
However, this wouldn't be a good solution for those with an inhalation allergy.
Maybe the ban could extend to all foods when there is a specific request."

cqs.cq: Would banning peanuts on specific flights or a peanut-free buffer zone actually cause a significant reduction in the risk of exposure for individuals with peanut allergies?

Do you have a scientific study that supports the notion that a peanut-free buffer zone on flights is a more effective solution for peanut allergy sufferers than simply choosing airlines that don't serve peanuts?
If airline staff can be trained to accommodate peanut allergies, why can't they also be trained to accommodate inhalation allergies by banning foods that cause them?
If airlines can be accommodating to customers with peanut allergies, why can't they also take extra precautions to minimize exposure to peanuts, rather than completely banning them?

PracticalJo_179_1.input:
PracticalJo: "Take peanuts off of planes.
Safety first.
It is not only airborne particles that are problematical,
it is also the crumbs, whole peanuts that "get away" from the passenger (i.e., dropped on floor or in seat), and residue left behind on seats, seat belts, floors, tray tables and other surfaces.
Ingestion or contact can trigger severe reactions.
Take peanuts and items containing peanuts/peanut butter (e.g., trail mix, peanut butter crackers) off of airplanes.
This is all the airlines need to do.
Most airlines already have a suitable replacement snack."

cqs.cq: What if the presence of peanuts on planes causes severe reactions in some passengers, affecting their health and potentially leading to medical emergencies?

Do you have any evidence that the risks of peanut crumbs and residue on airplanes are significant enough to warrant a complete ban on peanuts, rather than simply implementing more effective cleaning and hygiene protocols?

If peanuts pose a health risk to passengers due to their potential for airborne particles, crumbs, and residue, why would airline staff be exempt from similar health concerns regarding peanuts in their uniforms?
If peanuts pose such a significant health risk, why do airlines still allow passengers to bring peanut-containing items on board?

PracticalJo_179_2.input:
PracticalJo: "Anyone with a severe allergy already has EpiPens or other medications.
Airlines need not provide these.
As an outsider to the airline industry, it is hard for me to say what level of cleaning currently occurs on an aircraft.
Obviously, on quick turnaround layovers, flight crews only have time for a cursory cleaning.
I don't know.
If so, perhaps repeated standard cleanings without further peanut exposure would be sufficient?
The rule probably has the best chance of being enacted if it minimizes overall cost to the airline industry while meeting the desired safety requirements.
Personally, I would be satisfied if the rule simply called for removal of peanuts from aircraft and allowed the airlines to put forth a good faith effort at cleaning their fleets."

cqs.cq: What if the lack of any of the pieces of EpiPens or other medications on aircraft cause the allergy to manifest and affect the passengers' safety?
Do you have any evidence that the current cursory cleaning procedures used by airlines are sufficient to minimize the risk of peanut exposure for passengers with severe allergies?
If the airline industry can effectively clean their fleets to minimize peanut exposure, why should the rule not focus on that rather than mandating the availability of EpiPens for every passenger?
If the airlines are already not required to provide EpiPens, does this imply that the current standard of cleanliness on aircraft is sufficient to protect passengers with severe allergies?

Qubbin_80.input:
Qubbin: "I generally support the idea,
but it should be limited only to those fees which are variable,
They should not be allowed to list fees separately that are part of a ticket fee for every ticket issued,
This process serves no purpose other than to show a lower base fee.
That is misleading and meaningless.
If they want to show these components of a ticket, so be it,
but not to suggest a price which could never be exercised."

cqs.cq: Does allowing ticket issuers to separately list fees that are part of a ticket fee cause ticket prices to become misleading and meaningless?
Do you have a specific regulation or law that supports your claim that variable fees can only be listed separately for certain types of tickets?
If ticket fees are being broken down to show a lower base fee, does this not create a misleading and meaningless illusion of a lower overall cost?
If the fee components are already included in the overall ticket price, why should they be allowed to be listed separately and potentially mislead consumers with a lower base fee?

SWong_118_1.input:
SWong: "My son is severely allergic to peanuts and has allergic reactions as a result of being around people eating peanuts due to the peanut dust in the air.
We had to travel internationally and were able to work with the airline to book peanut free roundtrip flights after submitting a letter from my son's allergist.
The airline did everything they could including serving snacks without peanuts, putting allergy alert stickers on our seats, and making an announcement asking passengers to refrain from eating their peanut snacks.
My son was fine going to our destination but had an allergic reaction within minutes of being seated for our return trip.
Since he didn't eat any peanuts, we gave him some benadryl, moved him to a different row, and wiped down his new seat.
We were fortunate that his reaction was not severe enough to require an epipen injection and a trip to the hospital in another country."

cqs.cq: What if the airline's efforts to accommodate my son's peanut allergy were insufficient to prevent his allergic reaction, could this be a cause for the airline to take more comprehensive measures to ensure a safe environment for passengers with severe allergies?
Does the airline's provision of peanut-free accommodations and public announcement constitute a sufficient standard of care to protect passengers with severe peanut allergies?

If airline staff and staff members with peanut allergies are given accommodations and precautions to prevent allergic reactions, why should passengers with peanut allergies be left to fend for themselves without similar support?

If the airline took such precautions to accommodate your son's peanut allergy, why wasn't the airline's own staff or crew trained to recognize and respond to an allergic reaction as effectively as you were?

SWong_118_2.input:
SWong: "We suspect that he was reacting to peanut residue in the area of his seat from the previous flight.
We may not be so lucky next time because we have been told that the next reaction is even stronger than the last.
Even though we were on a peanutfree fight, my son still was not safe because of the peanut residue on the plane from a previous flight.
If peanuts are banned on all flights, my son would have been safe.
When an allergic reaction occurs high up in the sky over a huge ocean, and an epipen injection can only give a person an extra 20 minutes, there is not enough time to turn the plane around and take the person to the hospital.
I believe that it is reasonable to ban peanuts from airline flights if that assures the safety of a passenger that has a severe peanut allergy.
This decision could mean life or death for someone."

cqs.cq: Would banning peanuts from airline flights be a more effective preventative measure than relying solely on epipen injections in emergency situations?

Does the anecdotal experience of your son's peanut allergy reaction justify a blanket ban on peanuts on all flights, considering the potential economic and operational impacts on the airline industry?
If peanut allergies can be a matter of life or death for passengers, why should airline flights continue to expose passengers to the risk of peanut residue left over from previous flights?
If banning peanuts on flights would save lives, then why not take the same precautionary measures for other common allergens that can cause severe reactions, such as shellfish or latex?

SofieM_128.input:

However, I see no problem with regular passenger updates on the progress of the delay."

cqs.cq: What if the lack of regular passenger updates on the progress of the delay causes anxiety and affects the overall passenger experience?

SofieM_73.input:
SofieM: "the DOT got the idea of flight notifications from the airlines themselves,

"Carriers recognize the importance of timely and accurate flight information, as evidenced by the fact that many of the largest U.S. carriers promise through their customer service plans to provide passengers all known information about delays and cancellations as soon as they become aware of the issue" (48).
Any business which intends to survive has to satisfy its customers, otherwise the customers will simply stop buying their product, and the business will go bankrupt. Airlines themselves already thought up flight status notifications because there was customer demand for them.
I find it interesting that you claim neither passengers nor profits to be benefiting from the current state of air transit affairs.
Now, air fare is affordable (prices of air fares have decreased 25% since 1991) and more available to citizens than ever before.
Airlines like Southwest are benefiting exactly because they are offering low fares, serving their customer needs, which would seem to disprove your statement that both profits and passengers suffer in the status quo."

cqs.cq: Does the fact that airlines have voluntarily implemented flight status notifications, driven by customer demand, contradict the notion that passengers and profits are suffering equally in the current state of air transit affairs?

Do you have any evidence from the airlines' customer service plans or studies that demonstrate a significant number of passengers are consistently dissatisfied with the current state of flight information and notifications, despite the alleged benefits of low fares and increased availability?

If airlines have successfully implemented flight notifications to satisfy customer demand and subsequently increased profits, would the DOT's proposed rule be an example of the government intervening in a market where businesses are already meeting customer needs?
If airlines have already incorporated flight status notifications due to customer demand, then why does the DOT still need to intervene to require them?

SofieM_8.input:
SofieM: "In general, I think that blanket policies on this topic would be a bad idea,
because people have varying capacities to handle travel.
For example, the first time I ever flew without a parent (13 years ago), I was 7 years old, and I went with my older brother who was 10.
We flew from Chicago to Colorado with no incident.
However, that doesn't mean that every 7 or 10 year old can handle itmany can't, and shouldn't try.
It's something that the parents themselves should decide,
because they know their children better than the airlines do.
Also, be careful when talking about "minors" flying alone on airplanes.
I didn't turn 18 until I was already a sophomore in college
Different airlines will treat this issue differently.
Applying a blanket policy will take away the options that come in an open marketplace of ideas.
If I only had one option, because every airline was required to treat "minors" in the same manner, my travel choices would have been limited, not expanded."

cqs.cq: Do blanket policies on unaccompanied minors flying alone on airplanes actually cause a reduction in travel options for parents who can handle their children's varying capacities, rather than an increase in safety?
Do you have any evidence from studies or research that suggests parents are more equipped to make informed decisions about their children's ability to travel alone than the airlines themselves?

If SofieM's parents' ability to decide whether she could fly alone at 7 years old is seen as a valid example of parental responsibility, would the same logic not apply to parents of children who are slightly older, making blanket policies on airline travel restrictions similarly problematic?

If SofieM believes that parents should decide when their children can fly alone, then wouldn't she also believe that governments should decide when their citizens can be trusted with freedom of expression?

dberger_74_1.input:
dberger: "There must be a complete ban on tree nuts and peanuts on planes.
It is a closed space.
I am allergic to peanuts and almonds
and I am impacted every time I fly.
A nut free zone does not work
since the dust from nuts gets in the closed air system of the plane.
For the time that people are on planes there should be consideration of others who have no control as to the reactions they have to nuts.
For almost all other foods the allergy only occurs if the food is ingested
so you can easily avoid the allergic reaction but not eating the food.
This is not true for many of us with nut allergies
we react if other people are eating the food
since it is an airborne allergy.
I do fly but I have to take multiple Benadryl pills every 4 hours to keep from reacting to the airborne dust of the nuts.
This works for now
but I always wonder when it will no longer be enough.
An epipen is not the answer
as it lasts only look enough for the plane to land
which is not a practical solution when you are flying on a long flight over water
and would certainly be a much greater inconvenience to the other passengers than a ban on nut products on planes if the plane was able to land.
The rules airlines have are ridiculous
Southwest is not nut free
they will not serve nuts
but if you fly a late flight the peanuts are all over the floor and seats.
Some other airlines have the rows around you 'nut free'
but advise you they can do nothing if the person seated next to you brings nuts on and wants to eat them."

cqs.cq: Do the airlines' inability to effectively enforce nut-free zones on planes ultimately cause the allergic reactions experienced by passengers like you?

Do you have any scientific evidence or medical research to support the claim that airborne exposure to tree nuts and peanuts poses a significant risk of anaphylactic reactions to the extent that warrants a complete ban on their presence on planes?

If the airline industry can accommodate the concerns of passengers with nut allergies by designating nut-free zones, why can't they take a more comprehensive approach and ban the presence of nuts altogether on planes?

If airlines can provide a 'nut-free' section on a plane, why can't they enforce a complete ban on nut products on the entire plane to protect passengers like you who have no control over their reactions to airborne nut dust?

dberger_74_2.input:
dberger: "Other airlines with advance notice will not serve nuts
but all airlines allow passengers to bring on foods including nuts
and will not stop the person from eating them if they wish to.
So you can have a 'nut free' flight and the person sitting next to you can take out their package of peanuts and eat away
and the airlines will do nothing to help you.
Again all nuts should be banned from airplanes unless it is your own private plane  then go ahead and eat what you want."

cqs.cq: What if allowing passengers to bring and eat nuts on flights causes a higher risk of in-flight allergic reactions and potential lawsuits against airlines?

Does the airline's policy of allowing passengers to bring and consume nuts, while not enforcing their own "nut-free" policy, demonstrate a double standard in prioritizing the comfort of one passenger over others?

If airlines allow passengers to bring and consume their own nuts on flights, would they not also allow passengers to bring and consume their own peanuts, thereby rendering the 'nut-free' flight option redundant?
If airlines can accommodate nut-free flights, why can't they also accommodate nut-free seating, allowing passengers with severe nut allergies to have a safe flying experience?

dlpoole_223_1.input:
dlpoole: "Bumping compensation should apply to all carriers
because of the increasing use of regional carriers to serve smaller markets
and their no lesser disruptiveness and potential expense to the traveler.
Passengers may lack check cashing privileges away from their home airport, yet face unplanned and likely elevated expenses after being "bumped."
They should have a mandatory option of cash payment.
An credit card credit, if immediate, would be more secure and as useful to more passengers than either a check or cash.
The proposed compensation limits are too low to provide an incentive to the airlines to limit overbooking
and may be arbitrarily unfair to certain travelers.
The Wall Street Journal recently reproposed a 1977 proposal by the late economist Julian Simon of an auction that would offer bumped passengers a gradually rising reward for giving up their seat.
The arguments are rather compelling.
See the WSJ, June 8, 2010, "Auctions for Overbooking"  or"

cqs.cq: What if the potential for increased compensation to bumped passengers through an auction system causes airlines to overbook more seats, thereby increasing the likelihood of bumping and the associated financial burden for travelers?

Does the Wall Street Journal's proposed auction system, as advocated by Julian Simon, indeed provide a more equitable solution for bumped passengers than the current compensation limits, or is it a flawed alternative that may lead to further exploitation?
If passengers have the option to auction their seat, would this not incentivize airlines to overbook and limit bumping, effectively undermining the purpose of the proposed compensation?

If the Wall Street Journal's proposed auction system is effective in incentivizing airlines to limit overbooking, then why does the current compensation system not already achieve the same goal with its proposed limits?

dlpoole_223_2.input:
dlpoole: "http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703303904575293011757655060.html
The airlines will overbook so as to optimize their financial results under any given set of caps,
so some passengers will still be involuntarily denied boarding on overbooked flights.
An auction will more accurately price the delay
and the sellers (the delayed passenger(s)) will be left with no complaint that it was involuntary.
An auction would also force the carriers to face the cost of overbooking in customer dissatisfaction and better inform their flight scheduling decisions.
I recall hearing seats being auctioned by progressive increases in the promised compensation by gate agents,
but that was long, long ago and under far greater seat availability and lower probabilities of cascading delays and subsequent denials of boarding for those who took the compensation.
Those procedures were surely regulated by DOT,
(perhaps when the industry was more heavily regulated,)
so perhaps those earlier rules should be revisited."

cqs.cq: Will the auction-based system cause a significant reduction in the number of passengers being involuntarily denied boarding on overbooked flights, thus affecting the overall customer satisfaction and the airlines' financial results?

Do you have any scientific evidence or data that supports the claim that an auction system would more accurately price the delay and reduce customer dissatisfaction, as you suggest, rather than relying on the current overbooking and compensation procedures?

Would the auction-based system of compensating delayed passengers for voluntarily giving up their seats on overbooked flights be more effective in reducing customer dissatisfaction and encouraging more accurate pricing of delays than the current system, which often results in involuntary denials of boarding?
If the airlines' auctions accurately price the delay and the sellers are left with no complaint, why would we still need regulations to protect passengers from involuntary denial of boarding?

drgreg_181_1.input:
drgreg: "I believe airlines should be forced to fully reimburse confirmed passengers whenever the airline changes flight schedules after booking.
I frequently reserve flights up to one year in advance, in order to secure the lowest price and best seat.
I do this even though the airline will charge me $150 (plus fare difference) to change my itinerary for personal reasons once booked.
However, the airline frequently change flight schedules for confirmed passengers without compensation, nor consideration of passengers' plans.
For example, a trip to Europe on United Airlines has now been changed 7 times by the airline since I confirmed my reservation in December 2009.
The resulting changes have added nearly 5 hours to the total trip, plus I'm now required to leave at 3AM for the airport (instead of my original departure of 8AM), and I return after midnight, rather than a more reasonable 10:30PM.
In addition, United Airlines has not offered to waive the change fee, nor provide seats on alternate dates or airline partners.
If I'm required to pay exorbitant fees to the airlines to change my original itinerary, due to personal circumstances, then the airlines should also be required to compensate inconvenienced passengers in full AND provide satisfactory alternate travel arrangements comparable to the original flight schedule.
Perhaps this would force the airlines to recognize the hardships they create for passengers when schedules are revised after passengers have already received confirmed flights and make related travel arrangements."

cqs.cq: If airlines are allowed to charge passengers significant fees to change their itineraries, do they also have a corresponding responsibility to compensate passengers for the resulting inconveniences and provide suitable alternative travel arrangements?

Do you have any personal anecdotes or research supporting the claim that airlines are consistently changing flight schedules without adequate compensation for passengers, rather than relying solely on the example from your personal experience?
If airlines can charge passengers to change their flight schedules due to personal reasons, why should passengers not have the right to hold airlines accountable for their own schedule changes?

If airlines can charge passengers for changing their flight itineraries due to personal reasons, then why should they not be held accountable for the inconvenience caused by their own schedule changes, which can also require passengers to alter their plans?

elizwestley_222.input:
elizwestley: "A peanutfree table is less likely to have smears of peanut butter on/under it.
Risk of exposure is reduced
which is not as good as eliminated but is better than full exposure.
I see the parallel with these flight proposals.
Ban peanut products.
Yes, people will "sneak" them.
However, the risk will still be reduced over the nothing that we are doing now."

cqs.cq: Does banning peanut products entirely eliminate the risk of exposure, or does it merely shift the risk to individuals who will still find ways to consume them, thereby reducing the overall risk but not eradicating it entirely?
Do you have a scientific study that supports the claim that banning peanut products would be more effective in reducing exposure to peanut allergens than the current measures in place?
If a peanut-free table is considered less likely to have smears of peanut butter on it, does that not imply that a peanut-free airline would be less likely to have peanut products on board?
If we acknowledge that banning peanut products would still reduce the risk, shouldn't we consider that the current lack of regulation also reduces the risk, albeit to a lesser extent?

elizwestley_68.input:

Flight personnel need more education on this."

cqs.cq: What if flight attendants are not adequately trained to handle allergy alerts, and this lack of training causes them to incorrectly provide allergenic items to passengers, which can lead to severe health consequences?
Do you think flight personnel should be trained to recognize and respond to common food allergies, such as peanut allergies, to prevent potentially life-threatening situations?
If airlines are trained to handle food allergies, why would they not also be trained to handle life-threatening conditions like peanut allergies?
If flight attendants are trained to handle medical emergencies, why are they not also trained to handle a potentially life-threatening allergy like peanut allergy?

golff4fun_155.input:
golff4fun: "I think it's important to stress the real reason that aircraft is not returning to the gate.
Once the aircraft pulls away from the jetway, the crew is on the clock.
They are not being paid while sitting at a gate.

 < this message is answering to >

golff4fun_162.input:
golff4fun: "Since weight seems to be the issue with charging extra fees for checked luggage,
the 98 lb person should pay less for a ticket than the 250 pounder.
I have thought that from the very beginning when the airlines introduced this new fee."
 < this message is answering to > 
NYCMuscleman18: "I know this sounds silly,

hgranato_211.input:
hgranato: "As an adult with a severe tree nut allergy,
I certainly empathize with the folks with peanut allergies.
That said, it seems arbitrary to ban peanuts and not tree nuts
given the likelihood of a serious reaction is fairly similar.
If the airlines could have precautions in place,
that would be a positive step.
However, supplying those items really should be the responsibility of the person with the allergy or, if it is a child, the caretaker.
Further, the logistics of implementing such a ban would be almost impossible.
Are we looking at searching passenger luggage, banning the sale of all foods with peanuts
(and since most carry the "made in a facility that also handles", you'd be looking at eliminating almost all foods)
and regulating all restaurants at airports as well?
Unfortunately, personal responsibility and proactive steps on the part of the person with the allergy is likely the only viable solution."

cqs.cq: What if the lack of personal responsibility and proactive steps on the part of individuals with tree nut allergies causes them to miss out on potentially life-saving measures?
Do you have any evidence that the likelihood of a severe reaction to tree nuts is indeed similar to that of peanuts, given the differing prevalence and handling procedures in the food industry?
If airlines can require passengers to declare and handle food allergies, why not also require passengers with tree nut allergies to declare and handle their own tree nut concerns?
If airlines can take precautions to protect passengers with tree nut allergies, why should they not also take similar precautions to protect passengers with peanut allergies?

howie_201.input:
howie: "First, stop reading that propaganda magazine.
Publications like that only serve to create fear in minds like yours.
Second, how old is your kid?
If under 5, relax the sensitivity will probably go away by the time he is 5.
Third, go to a real doctor  not an allergist and see if there is really even a problem at all.
This supposed plague of food allergies is the result of very clever advertising by this profession of pseudoscientists.
Allergists are not doctors.
I sincerely doubt you "know plenty of people who will die if they do have peanuts or breathe in peanut dust".
Almost noone is actually that allergic.
Lot's of people think they are much worse off than they really are.
Methinks you have an agenda.
Highly suspicious that the child of a physician who is hyper aware of bad things that can happen coincidentally has not one, but three life threatening allergies.
Have you heard of Munchasen by Proxy?
Do you realize that most kids have mild reactions to various food items that they invariably grow out of by the age of 5?
Food allergies have to be the most overblown imagined health problem of our time.
Hypochondriacs all."
 < this message is answering to > 
jsooudi: "I'm a physician, epidemiologist, and mother to a four year old boy with allergies to milk, peanuts and egg.
My son's dairy allergy is severe,
and he has had numerous lifethreatening anaphylactic reactions to trace amounts of milk,
which required multiple doses of epinephrine and trips to the Emergency Department.
Tests indicate that his peanut allergy is worse,
but fortunately he has only been exposed once to a peanut;
he put one in his mouth and had a relatively mild  reaction.
I've traveled with my children
and despite calling ahead, making requests, and reminding employees at the door, I've rarely had respect, let alone consistency, in any kind of peanutfree buffer zone or flight.
Several years ago Continental Airlines customer service headquarters informed me that they would serve peanuts on all flights as they were unable to guarantee a peanut free flight.
(So why not hand out weapons since they can't guarantee a weapon free flight either?)
I've sat with my epi pen in hand on a filthy flight with visible peanut crumbs on the floor while a flight attendant insisted on offering peanuts to the passengers around me because "it was their right."
Fortunately for me, my son's peanut allergy is not severe enough that it prohibits us from air travel.
Now that he is old enough to not put things in his mouth, and to protect himself, we are safer.
However, I know of many, many others in the allergy community, children and adults who simply can NOT fly.
My son's dairy allergy is quite severe.
The world would be a much safer place for us if no one consumed milk near him.
If his skin touches anything that once touched milk, even if it was partially cleaned, he will get severe hives.
If he consumes even less than a drop, within seconds his lips, eyes and face will swell, he will be covered in hives, vomit, and be gasping for breath.
Without epinephrine he would probably die within minutes.
But milk is ubiquitous,
and milk allergy relatively uncommon,
so we must protect ourselves.
Peanut allergy is common,
and it is a simple step to serve an alternative peanut based snacks for a short period of time.
So why is this a big problem?
The vast majority of potential reactions would be eliminated by simply avoiding snacks that have peanuts or peanut butter as an ingredient.
Peanut oil is known to contain very little of the actual peanut protein,
and would be of little risk in an airborne environment.
As a physician, I have responded to the call from airline staff asking for emergency medical assistance.
I am well aware of how expensive and inconvenient it is to ground a plane.
In addition, most epipens come in two pack doses,
each of which are good for maybe 10 to 15 minutes.
Which in a severe anaphylactic reaction is simply not enough time between the beginning of a reaction and the patient reaching EMS.
I've found that other passengers, as a rule, are extremely supportive,
and are more than happy to help with a fellow passengers safety.
I think the people commenting on this site would react entirely differently were they seated next to an allergic child on a plane.
Of course they would refrain from eating peanuts for a few hours if they knew it would hurt someone they were looking in the face.
But I am sympathetic to individuals who are unhappy with yet another discomfort inflicted on air travelers.
This restriction is designed to protect people with allergies from the airlines callous disregard for cleanliness and for our safety, not from our fellow passengers.
"Hi.  My name is Steven.  I am 4 years old.
I am allergic to peanuts, eggs and cow milk.
If I eat a peanut I'll get sick.
I ate a nut one time and got a big bump on my lip and it swelled up and it was hard to breathe.
It was scary and my dad gave me some medicine that made it better.
I would like for them to not give out peanuts so I won't get sick because I'm allergic.
Everybody should drink Sprite and eat Pringles and Pretzels.""

cqs.cq: Does the severe and potentially life-threatening allergy of a 4-year-old child justify the complete restriction of peanuts on flights, when the vast majority of people who claim to be allergic have mild reactions that they grow out of by the age of 5?

Do you, as a physician, have any personal experience or scientific evidence to support the claim that the peanut allergy is a relatively rare condition that can be safely managed with epinephrine and that the risk of anaphylactic reactions is low enough to disregard peanut-free zones in airlines?

If a doctor, epidemiologist, and mother to a child with severe allergies is concerned about the potential risks of peanut exposure on flights, why should the airline's inability to guarantee a peanut-free environment exempt them from providing alternative snacks or taking measures to accommodate passengers with allergies?

If your son has had multiple life-threatening anaphylactic reactions to trace amounts of milk, and yet you still consider the risk of peanut allergy to be relatively mild, are you not setting a double standard by advocating for a peanut-free environment when you yourself have had to deal with the very real risks associated with your son's dairy allergy?

howie_208.input:
howie: "Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from eating peanuts?
Didn't think so.
Most food allergies are imagined.
You clearly have a financial interest in promoting the myth of food allergy.
If someone is actually that allergic, they should stay home and not inconvenience the rest of us."
 < this message is answering to > 
Doctor-Mom: "I would support a full ban of peanut products on any airline.
Peanut reactions can be life threatening.
An individual doesn't have to consume the product to have a life threatening reaction.
They can have contact or inhalation reactions.
Restricting to certain flights is not enough,
as residue can be rampant.
Providing buffer zones is a thoughtful gesture,
but from a practical point of view does not work.
With so many food choices available, why are peanuts a necessary choice?
I am a physician , and author on the subject.
I have free food allergy online support forums with 3000 members.
http://www.drmomsallergyrx.com/
I would be more than willing to work with you in any way on this decision making process.
The allergic community is so grateful that you are allowing our voices to be heard.
The decision you are considering could save many lives."

cqs.cq: Does a physician who has a financial interest in promoting the myth of food allergy, and has a website with a large following of people with food allergies, have a potential conflict of interest that could influence their recommendation to ban peanut products on airlines?
Do you have any documented cases or peer-reviewed studies to support the claim that peanut reactions can be life-threatening through contact or inhalation without a food product being consumed?
If the doctor has a vested interest in promoting food allergy awareness, does that not create a potential conflict of interest in advocating for a full ban of peanut products on airlines?
If your online support forums have 3000 members, does that imply that the issue of food allergies is more widespread than you claim it to be?

howie_213.input:
howie: "While I still dispute whether your reaction will be as severe as you believe, at least you realize that it is your responsibility to take precautions.
Your ailment is not shared by the general population,
and should not be an excuse to infringe upon the rights of others."
 < this message is answering to > 
hgranato: "As an adult with a severe tree nut allergy,
I certainly empathize with the folks with peanut allergies.
That said, it seems arbitrary to ban peanuts and not tree nuts
given the likelihood of a serious reaction is fairly similar.
If the airlines could have precautions in place,
that would be a positive step.
However, supplying those items really should be the responsibility of the person with the allergy or, if it is a child, the caretaker.
Further, the logistics of implementing such a ban would be almost impossible.
Are we looking at searching passenger luggage, banning the sale of all foods with peanuts
(and since most carry the "made in a facility that also handles", you'd be looking at eliminating almost all foods)
