Unfortunately, personal responsibility and proactive steps on the part of the person with the allergy is likely the only viable solution."

cqs.cq: Would the lack of personal responsibility and proactive steps by individuals with allergies actually cause a significant impact on the overall effectiveness of the precautions taken by airlines?
Do you consider the responsibility of individuals with allergies to take precautions to be a more feasible solution than implementing sweeping bans on specific foods in public spaces?

If airlines can provide precautions for passengers with severe allergies, why can't they also accommodate passengers with severe cultural or socio-economic allergies, such as those who are severely disadvantaged by systemic injustices?

If the airline industry can implement precautions for passengers with peanut allergies, wouldn't they also be responsible for taking proactive steps to prevent the spread of your allergy-related disease, despite it not being a shared affliction among the general population?

howie_238.input:
howie: "Mulder is right on point.
Most food allergies are completely imagined.
An overly anxious parent gets it in her head that little jimmy might have had a hive after someone had peanuts in his vicinity,
and now he's "deathly allergic".
Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from peanuts (other than by choking on them)?
I sincerely doubt it.
Peanuts are incredibly nutritious,
almost universally enjoyed,
and quite filling in a small serving.
Simply put, pound for pound there is no better food on the planet.
This whole antipeanut hysteria is ridiculous!
Leave my peanuts alone!
If you are one of the incredibly rare people that have an actual medically diagnosed severe allergy to this wonderful food, then you better never leave the house because peanuts are everywhere.
You certainly should not be flying."

cqs.cq: Do the risks associated with peanuts being "everywhere" outweigh the benefits of consuming them, especially considering the rarity of severe peanut allergies?
Can you provide any reputable medical or scientific evidence supporting the claim that peanuts are the most nutritious food on the planet?

If the overwhelming presence of peanuts on planes is a legitimate concern for those with severe allergies, why are airlines not required to provide more comprehensive allergy accommodations rather than simply labeling the peanuts as a warning?
If peanuts are indeed so nutritious and widely enjoyed, shouldn't we prioritize education and awareness over blanket bans and restrictions that stigmatize a rare but legitimate allergy?

kateinhawaii_103.input:
kateinhawaii: "I personally have suffered from peanut allergies for over 40 years.
If there are packaged peanuts served on board a flight, it's 100% guaranteed that I will have a reaction from the peanut dust.
I do not agree with a buffer zone for a couple of reasons.
For me, it's the dust in the air.
Someone posted that the air circulates peanut dust right out of the air
but apparently not quick enough to prevent a life threatening reaction.
You know, airlines tried to create nonsmoking zones on airplanes but that didn't work either.
I have been on flights where nasty (and do I mean NASTY) flight attendants have made sarcastic remarks about me and my allergies especially on one Delta flight.
Northwest was great
because they respected their passengers enough to address their concerns
and prohibited peanuts altogether.
It was as much a relief to walk onto one of their flights as it was to walk onto one of the first smoke free flights!
Smokers use to use the same logic and reasoning to justify smoking on flights as these peanut proponents are using now.
I flew on many smoking flights and never needed to inject myself so that I could breathe
I can't say the same for flights with peanuts."

cqs.cq: Do the airlines' policies regarding peanut-free zones ultimately cause a significant reduction in the number of passengers who suffer from peanut allergies?

Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that a buffer zone would completely eliminate the risk of peanut dust circulation on an airplane, considering the air circulation patterns and the severity of your peanut allergies?
If airlines can establish smoke-free zones to protect the health of smokers, why can't they establish peanut-free zones to protect the health of passengers with peanut allergies?
If airlines can effectively ban smoking for the sake of passenger health, why can't they also ban peanuts for the sake of passenger health?

lauraclare_136.input:
lauraclare: "I have two children with potentially life threatening allergies to peanuts.
Unlike what one person commented, this is not a latest illness fad.
The latest research indicates that peanut allergy doubled in children from 1997 to 2002 and that number continues to increase.
It is one of the most deadly food allergies.
The presence of nuts on planes is a real fear.
While my kids have other potentially deadly food allergies,
peanuts pose a unique risk.
Nuts break into fine pieces with dust that can become airborne.
Peanut butter is sticky and gets wiped on seats and tray tables.
Even the slightest microscopic amount of nuts can create an anaphylactic reaction.
Although EpiPens can help,
they are not 100% effective
and should not be considered a solution to the risk peanuts pose to allergic individuals on planes.
Additional steroids, Benadryl shots, oxygen and other medical intervention may be necessary to stop an anaphylactic reaction.
EpiPens may need to be administered every 15 to 30 minutes as well.
People still die even with intervention.
Please help protect people by offering people the opportunity to get peanut free flights or ban the sale and serving of nut products on the planes."

cqs.cq: Would the potential risks of peanut exposure on planes be more effectively mitigated by banning the sale and serving of nut products on planes, rather than offering peanut-free flights?

Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that the risk of peanuts on planes is so significant that banning their sale and serving on flights would be a more effective solution than requiring airlines to offer peanut-free flights?
If peanuts pose a unique risk to passengers with life-threatening allergies, should airlines prioritize passenger safety over the convenience of offering peanuts on flights?
If peanuts pose a significant risk to life-threatening allergic individuals, why should airlines prioritize profits over passenger safety by allowing the sale and serving of nut products on planes?

mcliverty_188_1.input:
mcliverty: "Lack of space should be at the top of the list of issues the airlines need to address.
Whenever you hear about new airliners (the big 300) they don't mention improved arm and leg room.
I can handle the commuters because typically you aren't on there long, but cross country is killer in those economy class seats.
If they were ergonomically designed and comfortable, maybe they would be better, but they are terrible for lumbar and leg support.
You could probably save space by using more comfortable materials that are slimmer in design.
Even the same leg room with a 3" wider seat would be great.
Maybe a pop up foot rest/block from the floor to rest your feet on..
Air travel has really just become a necessary evil you have to survive.
It's certainly not something enjoyed or eagerly anticipated any longer."

cqs.cq: Would the increased comfort and ergonomics of airline seats cause a significant increase in passenger satisfaction and loyalty, ultimately affecting the airline's revenue and market share?

Do you believe that prioritizing passenger comfort and ergonomic design in aircraft seating is more crucial to the airline industry's long-term success than the initial cost savings of minimalist designs?
If airlines prioritize profits over passenger comfort, can they be expected to effectively address the ergonomic issues that make long-haul flights unbearable?
Would airlines prioritize passenger comfort over profit if the lack of space in economy class is indeed a major issue?

mcliverty_188_2.input:
mcliverty: "I avoid it if I can and consolidate my trips whenever possible.
I would rather drive 1012 hours in my car than fly at this point.
I travel with my dog about twice a year.
Because he is 28 pnds, he has to be checked and travel in cargo.
It costs anywhere from $300400 round trip to take him.
I would rather be allowed to put him in a carrier that is secured by the seat belt and have him travel in the seat next to me (that I purchase a ticket for), especially if I have to pay the same or more for his ticket in cargo as I do for mine.
The cost and stress of handing him over to cargo is wearing me down and I will most likely not take him on some future trips so they will loose my business.
If the airlines could make their processes more customer & dog friendly, it would make travel much more enjoyable.
I'm sure my dog would behave as well or better than some humans in the cabin."

cqs.cq: What if the increased cost and stress associated with shipping pets through cargo cause a decrease in pet owners choosing to travel with their companions?
Do you think your concerns about your dog's travel experience are representative of a larger issue with airline pet policies that affects the loyalty and business of pet owners?
Would allowing pets to travel in the cabin with their owners, secured by a seat belt, not enhance customer satisfaction and potentially increase loyalty to airlines?

If the convenience and cost savings of allowing pets to travel in the cabin are so significant, why should airlines prioritize the comfort and safety of their human passengers over that of their canine ones?

mfball__143.input:
mfball: "we listen to the top five Democrats
the Republicans had the top eleven or so in their debate
Chafee seemed like a trainwreck in the debate
O'Malley did alright
You might be right about his chances at getting the nomination
some candidates' chances could be influenced greatly by the amount of media coverage they're getting
People were swearing up and down that Bernie didn't have a shot
no one had ever heard of him
Hillary was the only one getting airtime
now he's getting a lot of attention
 he's a competitive candidate
 I don't know a lot about O'Malley
nobody's been talking about him or interviewing him
I don't think he came off as a "sideshow" candidate in the debate
If he started getting more attention, I imagine he could probably pull numbers at least as good as the lowest of the Republicans that are still being talked about"

cqs.cq: Would the increased media coverage of O'Malley influence his chances of getting the nomination more than his performance in the debate?
Do you think the increased media coverage of Bernie Sanders is solely responsible for his rise in the polls, or are there other factors at play?

If the media attention and debate performance of an unknown, low-funded Democrat like Bernie Sanders can elevate his chances, why would a well-funded, well-known Republican candidate like Jeb Bush not receive similar benefits from his debate performance?
If the media coverage can significantly influence the chances of some candidates, does the lack of attention given to O'Malley in the past not also limit his potential to become a viable candidate?

msrocker_127.input:
msrocker: "I agree with many others that even 3 hours is too long..
I think it should be 2
and should apply to all flights regardless of what airport, airline, destination, etc.
People are people no matter where they are
and should not be subjected to being miserable after paying a fee to fly somewhere!
Personally I have anxiety issues
and not being able to get out of an enclosed space is extremely stressful.
I think the airlines will now be forced to do all they can to prevent these delays.
Even though all will not be possible to prevent
I think there will be much less episodes wtih these new rules.
I think it goes a LONG ways to alleviate frustration
if we were informed in detail every 30 minutes.
I have been stranded on a plane 3 times
thankfully not more than 1 1/2 hours
but on one of these flights we were informed regularly along the way
and it made all the difference."

cqs.cq: What if the reduction of flight delays from 3 hours to 2 hours causes a significant increase in the stress levels of anxious passengers, thereby affecting their overall travel experience?
Do you have any personal experience or scientific evidence that supports the claim that informing passengers about flight delays every 30 minutes can alleviate frustration by a significant margin?

If passengers are considered to be treated equally regardless of their airport, airline, or destination, would airlines not also be held accountable for providing equal standards of service and communication across all flights?
If the elimination of flight delays is the primary concern, then why not prioritize transparency over airline-specific or airport-specific rules?

secretcurse__137.input:
secretcurse: "Don't hold your breath for the Green Party Presidential Debate on any of our major news networks
a person that wants to run on the Green Party (or any other party) ticket absolutely has that right and should be able to express their views in public
there's no obligation to give them equal time on privately owned networks compared to the Democratic or Republican candidates that actually have a shot at winning the election
Clinton is extremely likely to win the Democratic nomination
Sanders has a shot at beating her
O'Malley, Webb, and Chafee are all sideshow candidates in the primary
just like the nominees from the Green, Libertarian, and Communist parties will be in the general election
Everyone should be allowed to express themselves in public places freely, but a cable news network isn't a public place"

cqs.cq: Does the unequal access to major news networks for Green Party candidates impact their ability to effectively cause their ideas to influence the general public's perception of their viability as a potential presidential candidate?

Does the First Amendment's protection of free speech and the right to express one's views in public places not apply to individuals who wish to run for public office and participate in televised debates?

Would the argument that privately owned networks are not a public place justify limiting the free speech rights of a Green Party candidate in the same way that public streets are not restricted for the same candidate?
If a privately owned news network is not considered a public place, then shouldn't the same network have the right to decide who they give airtime to, rather than the government or public demand?

secretcurse__139.input:
secretcurse: "The first debate was already limited to five people
According to the FEC
171 people have officially declared their candidacy for the Democratic Party nomination with the FEC (sort by party to see the 171 people a bit easier)
Do you think every single one of the 171 people that have filed the paperwork with the FEC declaring their candidacy deserves their fair shot at expressing themselves at the first debate"

cqs.cq: Does the debate's limited size unfairly exclude deserving candidates who may have a strong argument but lack the resources or connections to secure a spot?
Do you believe the FEC's requirements for the debate should be more inclusive and not limited to just five candidates, given the large number of candidates who have filed with the FEC?

If a company with 171 employees is considered too large for a CEO to effectively manage the company, why should the first debate not be limited to a smaller number of candidates to ensure a more effective and engaging discussion?

If a limited debate is essential to give a fair voice to the 171 candidates, then why should the same principle not apply to the 171 candidates who are still waiting for their turn to participate in the second debate?

smg_72.input:
smg: "It has become abundantly clear that commercial airline travel is a "race to the bottom" that satisfies needs of neither passengers nor airline profits.
A change of environment, which can only be imposed from outside the industry is needed.
Imposition of common sense regulations,
would level the playing field and remove the impetus for airlines to costcut in this area.
The results would be better service to customers and a renormalization of the playing field from which the airlines compete without fear of being undercut.
This goes for most of the proposed new regulations.
I sincerely believe that these regulations are in the best interests of both airlines and passengers."

cqs.cq: What if the imposition of common sense regulations does not actually level the playing field, but instead creates a new set of incentives for airlines to find alternative, regulatory loopholes?

Do you have any evidence from the airline industry itself that shows imposing common sense regulations would not lead to a significant increase in operational costs, thereby undermining the very benefits you claim it would bring?

If airline industry profit margins are the primary motivator for undercutting costs, would imposing common sense regulations not also level the playing field for airline employees who are often the backbone of the industry?
If airline profits are prioritized over passenger needs, does this not undermine the claim that imposing regulations is in the best interests of both airlines and passengers?

smr_174_1.input:
smr: "The problem of whether to deplane or not is a tricky one.
On one side is the fact that sitting for an excessive amount of time is uncomfortable at best and unhealthy at worst.
However, on the other side there will be considerable time lost with the deplaning and reboarding.
One item which should be addressed is food and drink.
If the airline would normally have food for the passengers on that flight it seems silly to deny access to anything more than a bag of peanuts and a glass of water.
This happened to my husband last week on a Delta flight from Newark to Amsterdam.
The passengers were sitting on the plane for over six hours, at the gate,
but they were only offered one bag of peanuts and a glass of water or orange juice.
The plane eventually took off at approximately 1 a.m.,
when it should have taken off at 6.40 the previous evening."

cqs.cq: Will the lack of food options on flights cause passengers to experience fatigue, discomfort, and potentially even health issues, thus affecting their overall travel experience?

Do you have any evidence that passengers who are denied food and drink on a delayed flight are more likely to experience discomfort and health issues than those who are provided with standard in-flight amenities?
Would the airlines' decision to deny passengers food and drink during a prolonged delay resemble a hospital's decision to withhold medical care during a prolonged wait?

If airline passengers are entitled to basic amenities like food and drink, then why would they be left with only peanuts and water or orange juice for an extended period of over six hours, particularly when the flight is delayed by several hours?

smr_174_2.input:
smr: "The dinner was not served until the normal point in the flight, somewhere over the Atlantic!
Allowing passengers off the plane into a holding area would not give them access to food and drink,
but would let them move around.
However, when passengers expect food to be served on a flight they will often depend on that being served
and an excessive delay in serving meals could be hazardous to some people's health,
especially when on a connecting flight
so there has been no opportunity to purchase food and drinks at the airport."

cqs.cq: What if the excessive delay in serving meals causes a passenger's health issue to manifest and affect their ability to stay on the flight?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that the delay in serving meals on a flight poses a significant health risk to passengers, especially on connecting flights?
If passengers are held in a holding area without access to food and drink, would this not be analogous to prisoners being detained without basic necessities?
If passengers have a right to food and water during the flight, should airlines be required to serve meals at the normal point, even if it means allowing passengers off the plane into a holding area?

travellots_133_1.input:
travellots: "There should be no discrimination in how a passenger is bumped or compensated just because they may have paid less for a ticket or used frequent flyer miles.
Airline tickets are not lottery tickets.
One does not purchase a ticket hoping to reach a certain destination.
Same as if one pays $4 for a cup of coffee or $1, the cup is supposed to have coffee in it.
The price does not dictate that "maybe" you will get the product or service.
Also, the airline decides what prices or miles are used to purchase a promise to get you from point A to point B.
If they can not afford to give  a ticket for that price, they should not sell it.
When you reserve a ticket, the assumption is that you will be taken from point A to point B by the times given by the airline.
A passenger does not purchase a ticket just to see if maybe they can get somewhere because they have nothing better to do."

cqs.cq: What if the lack of a guarantee of a seat or travel time affects the airline's ability to provide a service, ultimately causing them to lose revenue and potentially go out of business?
Do you think the airline's responsibility to provide a service to passengers, regardless of the ticket price or payment method, outweighs the customer's expectation of a guaranteed seat on a flight?
Should airline tickets not be considered a guaranteed contract rather than a gamble, with passengers entitled to the service promised regardless of the price or payment method?
If the airline promises a guaranteed seat from point A to point B, then why should a passenger who pays with miles or a lower ticket price be treated differently than one who pays the full price?

travellots_133_2.input:
travellots: "If compensation is not high enough, the airlines will not have an incentive to schedule properly.
It is not fair to allow airlines to discriminate against lower fared passengers or "free" passengers
since it is the airline, not the passenger or government, who gave that passenger a seat.
Otherwise, airlines can advertise low fares or con you into using them to build up your "miles" and then always bump you for someone who paid more.
In away,it is the same as being able to increase your ticket price anytime after purchase.
When you are bumped, there are a lot of hidden extra costs
It irks me that airlines seem to be treating passengers more and more as if they have nothing better to do but wait around in airports and not get to where the airline promised to bring them.
Again, the airline sets the agreed price or miles for a seat, no one else.
The incentives to the airline should be to get all confirmed passengers (regardless of price paid) to the destination promised."

cqs.cq: What if the airlines' ability to discriminate against lower-fared passengers or "free" passengers leads to a decrease in the overall efficiency of the airline's scheduling process?
Do you have any evidence that airlines' current scheduling practices and bumping of lower-fared passengers aligns with the agreed price or miles they set for a seat?

If airlines can profit from advertising low fares and then bumping passengers, why can't they be incentivized to treat all passengers, regardless of price paid, as customers deserving of the promised transportation?

If airlines have a responsibility to ensure that all passengers, regardless of the price they paid, arrive at their destination, why should they be allowed to prioritize higher-paying passengers over lower-paying passengers in the event of overbooking?

zuclinator_125.input:
zuclinator: "I know Delta serves peanuts
as I travel to and from Detroit on Delta.
I was really surprised to learn this
as I didn't know until I was on the plane and in the air.
shouldn't they tell people before they pay for a flight?
Oh and the two row minimum around a person with a peanut allergy is a joke.
Someone with a peanut allergy is not going to be protected by that!"

cqs.cq: Should airlines inform passengers with peanut allergies about the presence of peanuts on flights, thereby potentially affecting their decision to book or board a flight?
Do airlines such as Delta have a clear and transparent policy in place to inform passengers about peanut presence on flights, or is this information only shared incidentally during boarding?
If airline companies are required to notify passengers about peanuts being served, why are they not also required to inform passengers about other common allergens, such as gluten or shellfish?
If airlines inform passengers about potential allergens like peanuts, why do they not also provide clear and timely warnings about the presence of peanuts on flights?

TRUMP_114_1.input:
TRUMP: "we have been told through investigative reporting that he owes about $ 650 million to Wall Street and foreign banks
You learn a lot from financial disclosure
That I can tell you
you should go down and take a look at that
I 'm extremely underleveraged
The report that said $ 650
a lot of friends of mine that know my business
It 's not a lot of money relative to what I had
The buildings that were in question , they said in the same report , which was—actually , it was n't even a bad story , to be honest with you , but the buildings are worth $ 3.9 billion
the $ 650 is n't even on that
it 's not $ 650
It 's much less than that
I could give you a list of banks
I would—if that would help you , I would give you a list of banks
These are very fine institutions
very fine banks
I could do that very quickly
I am very underleveraged
I have a great company
I have a tremendous income
the reason I say that is not in a braggadocios way
It 's because it 's about time that this country had somebody running it that has an idea about money
we have $ 20 trillion in debt"

cqs.cq: Does having a debt of $650 million, as reported, not affect the way Trump perceives his financial situation and influences his decisions about his business and economic policies?

Do you have any financial records or statements from reputable sources that confirm your claims of being "underleveraged" and having a "great company" with a "tremendous income" when the reported debt of $650 million and the value of your buildings being $3.9 billion suggest otherwise?

If Trump's financial situation is characterized by a reported $650 million debt, yet he claims to be "underleveraged" and his company's assets are worth $3.9 billion, does this not imply a possible discrepancy between his public statements and actual financial reality?
If Trump claims to be underleveraged with a $3.9 billion building portfolio, why does his debt burden, reportedly $650 million, seem to be a significant financial concern?

TRUMP_114_2.input:
TRUMP: "our country 's a mess
it 's one thing to have $ 20 trillion in debt
Our airports are like from a third world country
You land at LaGuardia , you land at Kennedy , you land at LAX , you land at Newark , and you come in from Dubai and Qatar and you see these incredible—you come in from China , you see these incredible airports
we 've become a third world country
our bridges are good
everything 's in great shape
our airports
the worst of all things has happened
We owe $ 20 trillion
we 're a mess
We have n't even started
we 've spent $ 6 trillion in the Middle East
according to a report that I just saw
Whether it 's 6 or 5
 it looks like it 's 6
we could have rebuilt our country twice
it 's really a shame
it 's politicians like Secretary Clinton that have caused this problem
Our country has tremendous problems
We 're a debtor nation
We 're a serious debtor nation
we have a country that needs new roads , new tunnels , new bridges , new airports , new schools , new hospitals
we don't have the money
it 's been squandered on so many of your ideas"

cqs.cq: What if the country's current state of being "a mess" is a direct cause of the politicians, such as Secretary Clinton, making decisions that lead to further debt and underinvestment in essential infrastructure?

Do you have a specific example of a country that has successfully rebuilt its infrastructure and overcome its debt issues without a massive influx of foreign investment, to support your claim that the US could have rebuilt its country twice with the money spent in the Middle East?

If the United States is indeed a "third world country" with crumbling infrastructure and a significant debt, what does that say about the effectiveness of the politicians who have been in charge over the past few decades?

If we are indeed a "third world country" with "tremendous problems" and a "debtor nation", why did the politicians, including you, not prioritize nation-building over military interventions in the Middle East?

TRUMP_121_1.input:
TRUMP: "I do think it's time
it's all words
it's all sound bites
I built an unbelievable company
Some of the greatest assets anywhere in the world
real estate assets anywhere in the world
beyond the United States, in Europe, lots of different places
It's an unbelievable company
on occasion, four times, we used certain laws that are there
when Secretary Clinton talks about people that didn't get paid, first of all, they did get paid a lot, but taken advantage of the laws of the nation
if you want to change the laws, you've been there a long time, change the laws
you've been there a long time,
I take advantage of the laws of the nation
I'm running a company
My obligation right now is to do well for myself, my family, my employees, for my companies
that's what I do
what she doesn't say is that tens of thousands of people that are unbelievably happy and that love me"

cqs.cq: What if the emphasis on personal success and company growth as a primary obligation contradicts the notion that the company's success should also benefit the workers and the nation?
Does your business success justify the claim that you're running a company solely for the benefit of your family, employees, and yourself, rather than for the broader societal good?

If Trump's company is built on taking advantage of laws to his benefit, would that justify his claim that he's solely responsible for doing well for himself, his family, his employees, and his companies?

If he has been so successful in building his company and achieving financial success, why does he claim that his primary obligation is to do well for himself and his family, while seemingly disregarding the well-being of his employees?

TRUMP_121_2.input:
TRUMP: "I'll give you an example
We're just opening up on Pennsylvania Avenue right next to the White House
if I don't get there one way, I'm going to get to Pennsylvania Avenue another
we're opening the Old Post Office
I'm a year ahead of schedule
that's what this country should be doing
We build roads
they cost two and three and four times what they're supposed to cost
We buy products for our military
they come in at costs that are so far above what they were supposed to be
we don't have people that know what they're doing
When we look at the budget, the budget is bad to a large extent
we have people that have no idea as to what to do and how to buy
The Trump International is way under budget
way ahead of schedule
we should be able to do that for our country"

cqs.cq: Does the inefficiencies in the government's budgeting process and procurement of military products, as described by Trump, cause the country to be further behind schedule and over budget in other infrastructure projects?
Do you have any evidence that the successful management of the Trump International project is a suitable model for the entire US infrastructure and budget process?

If the Trump Organization can successfully complete a project under budget and ahead of schedule, why can't the US government, with its vast resources and expertise, accomplish similar feats in infrastructure development and military procurement?
If the Trump International is able to be built under budget and ahead of schedule, why can't the federal government accomplish the same efficiency in building roads and buying military products?

TRUMP_125_1.input:
TRUMP: "Secretary Clinton doesn't want to use a couple of words, and that's law and order
If we don't have it, we're not going to have a country
when I look at what's going on in Charlotte, a city I love, a city where I have investments, when I look at what's going on throughout various parts of our country, whether it's—I mean, I can just keep naming them all day long
I just got today the, as you know, the endorsement of the Fraternal Order of Police, we just—just came in
We have endorsements from, I think, almost every police group, very—I mean, a large percentage of them in the United States
We have a situation where we have our inner cities, African- Americans, Hispanics are living in hell
it's so dangerous
You walk down the street, you get shot
In Chicago, they've had thousands of shootings, thousands since January 1st
I'm saying, where is this
Is this a war-torn country
What are we doing
we have to stop the violence
In a place like Chicago, where thousands of people have been killed, thousands over the last number of years
almost 4,000 have been killed since Barack Obama became president"

cqs.cq: If the endorsement of police groups and the expression of concern about violence in inner cities are the only factors that can cause a politician to prioritize law and order, then does this imply that their policies are driven by short-term reaction rather than long-term solutions?
Do you have any data or research that supports the claim that the endorsement of the Fraternal Order of Police is a scientifically valid measure of law and order in a city like Chicago?

Does Trump's characterization of inner cities as "living in hell" and a "war-torn country" align with his own experiences and interactions with law enforcement, considering his claims of having endorsements from almost every police group in the United States?

If law and order is a fundamental aspect of a country, then can we justify the lack of effective policing in inner cities, particularly in places like Chicago, where thousands of lives have been lost?

TRUMP_125_2.input:
TRUMP: "almost 4,000 people in Chicago have been killed
 whether or not in a place like Chicago you do stop and frisk, which worked very well, Mayor Giuliani is here, worked very well in New York
It brought the crime rate way down
you take the gun away from criminals that shouldn't be having it
We have gangs roaming the street
in many cases, they're illegally here, illegal immigrants
they have guns
they shoot people
we have to be very strong
we have to be very vigilant
We have to be—we have to know what we're doing
 our police, in many cases, are afraid to do anything
We have to protect our inner cities
African-American communities are being decimated by crime, decimated
No"

cqs.cq: Does the approach of "stop and frisk" in cities like Chicago, which was successful in New York under Mayor Giuliani, necessarily translate to a solution for the complex issues of crime and immigration in urban areas?

Do you have a scientific study that supports the claim that "stop and frisk" policies, like the one Mayor Giuliani implemented in New York, are effective in reducing crime rates in urban areas like Chicago?
If stop and frisk effectively reduced crime in New York, would a similar approach in Chicago not be worth exploring despite the concerns of police being "afraid to do anything"?

If Mayor Giuliani's "stop and frisk" policy, which was effective in New York, is effective in reducing crime, then why can't the same approach be applied in Chicago, despite the fact that it led to the arrest of almost 4,000 people, regardless of their race or immigration status?

TRUMP_127.input:
TRUMP: "you're wrong
It went before a judge, who was a very against-police judge
It was taken away from her
our mayor, our new mayor, refused to go forward with the case
They would have won an appeal
If you look at it, throughout the country, there are many places where it's allowed"

cqs.cq: Does the lack of a clear explanation from the judge or the mayor about why the case was dismissed or appealed influence the public's perception of the legitimacy of the decision?
Can you provide evidence from a court decision or a reputable source to support the claim that a judge who is "very anti-police" would have a significant impact on the outcome of a case?
If a judge's personal bias and a mayor's refusal to pursue a case can result in a favorable outcome, shouldn't the same factors also apply to the appeal process?
If the system was indeed biased against the case, then how can we trust the verdict of the judge who was against the police?

I notice you bring that up a lot"

cqs.cq: Can the fact that Trump's father's company settled a federal lawsuit with no admission of guilt undermine his claims of moral superiority and honesty?
Do you have any evidence to support the claim that your father's company was involved in a federal lawsuit, as you mentioned, without any admission of guilt?
Does Trump's claim that he settled a lawsuit without admitting guilt imply that he believes his own actions, such as using racist images of Obama, should be considered similarly guiltless?
Doesn't your past actions, including sending out pictures of Barack Obama in a certain garb, undermine your current claims of moral superiority and hypocrisy?

TRUMP_112.input:
TRUMP: "That was more than a mistake
That was done purposely
That was not a mistake
When you have your staff taking the Fifth Amendment , taking the Fifth so they 're not prosecuted
when you have the man that set up the illegal server taking the Fifth
it 's disgraceful
this country thinks it's—really thinks it 's disgraceful , also
As far as my tax returns , you do n't learn that much from tax returns"

cqs.cq: If Trump's staff and associates taking the Fifth Amendment implies they are hiding something, then what does it say about the integrity of his claims that the actions were done "purposely" and not a mistake?
Do you have any expert opinions or scientific evidence to support the claim that a president's tax returns are inherently less revealing than other documents, such as the testimony of staff members?
If the President of the United States can use the Fifth Amendment to shield himself from accountability, why should the American public expect transparency from him?
Does the President's criticism of others for taking the Fifth Amendment undermine his own claims of innocence by not releasing his tax returns?

CLINTON_244_1.input:
CLINTON: "let me start by saying , words matter
they really matter when you are president
Words matter when you run for president
I want to reassure our allies in Japan and South Korea and elsewhere that we have mutual defense treaties and we will honor them
It is essential that America 's word be good
I know that this campaign has caused some questioning and worries on the part of many leaders across the globe
I 've talked with a number of them
I want to—on behalf of myself , and I think on behalf of a majority of the American people , say that , you know , our word is good
It 's also important that we look at the entire global situation
There 's no doubt that we have other problems with Iran
personally , I 'd rather deal with the other problems having put that lid on their nuclear program than still to be facing that
Donald never tells you what he would do
Would he have started a war ?
Would he have bombed Iran ?"

cqs.cq: What if the president's words being "good" are a cause for Iran to interpret the United States' commitment to mutual defense treaties as a guarantee of military action, rather than a promise of diplomatic resolution?
Do you have any evidence that Clinton's claim that "our word is good" has been a reliable guarantee in past instances, such as the failed promise of "leading from behind" in Libya?
If the US President's words are considered a promise to allies, does that not imply that the President's actions should align with those words, rather than contradicting them?

If Clinton's emphasis on the importance of America's word being good implies that a country's word is a reliable measure of its character, then does this not suggest that a leader's decision to bomb another country, like Iran, would be a reflection of that country's character?
